It is the same old story-stall, stall, stall.

While officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs are saying that they are men of good will and that they want to see that something is done about these men Senator Messner, with a broad smile on his face, has his less senior officers, such as Captain Manning, doing otherwise. Only today in the news services a Dr Spragg, who is a psychiatrist and who is a spokesman paid for by the Department-I do not know the extent of his research-was reported as saying, in speaking at a conference in departmental time about his use of departmental money, that he discounts any possibility of agent orange or any chemical being the cause of any veterans' problems, that the problems are due to post-traumatic stress disorders. I do not object to his saying that but I object to public money being used to put a one-sided argument in public when this Government and this Minister are not prepared to take that evidence and put it where it ought to be-before an impartial, judicial inquiry, call it a royal commission if you will. If the evidence is that good it will stand up. If it will not stand up it is time we sought justice and truth on behalf of these men.

That is all that they have ever asked for. I think it is reasonable for a married woman who has had two perfectly normal children and whose next child after her husband came back from Vietnam was born with a gross deformity still to want to have another child. But she has that doubt. Is there no compassion in this Government that it is not prepared to try to resolve that doubt or to pursue the evidence and let the truth fall where it may? That is all these men have ever asked for. That is all their families and wives have ever asked for. The Government has suppressed evidence. It refuses to answer the simplest questions. I have had a question on this subject on the Notice Paper since April 1981. A simple question directed to the Prime Minister is still unanswered, and it will not be answered. The attitude of the Government towards this issue is a national scandal. It can only purge its contempt of our ex-service organisations , it can only serve justice for members of the Vietnam Veterans' Association if it is prepared to grasp the nettle and say that they are entitled to a full examination of their problems within the framework of a judicial inquiry, nothing more. Nothing less will satisfy them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment, put forward so ably by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) and seconded by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), with regard to the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill 1982. I do this with a heavy heart because over the last months I have heard on a number of occasions attempts by the Opposition to get the Government to recognise and to move to the benefit of Vietnam veterans or forgotten soldiers. I should like briefly to go over the Vietnam tragedy of 14 years as it was seen and told by some creditable persons in recent months. On 9 September this year a Brisbane man shot himself dead. On the following day the Courier-Mail reported:

SPEECH.PARA: There are those who believe that bullet was fired not by his own hand, but by the Vietcong, 6000 miles away in South Vietnam 14 years ago.
His father, for example, 'The Vietnam war had a marked effect on my son,' he said yesterday.
'He saw some terrible things. He told me the Vietnamese woman who did his laundry was beheaded by the Vietcong and her head was nailed to the door.
'He'd been a very quiet, serious kid; he loved cars, he didn't drink or smoke.
'The only girl he ever had was his wife, Ira, and they were married just before he went to Vietnam.
'He just wasn't prepared for what he saw there-none of them was.'
A doctor has reported that when Graham saw the movie Apocalypse Now it re- created the war for him in all its three-dimensional sound-wracked reality.
'How,' Graham asked his wife, Ira, as he glanced at other filmgoers as the film blasted across the screen, 'can those people sit here and eat ice cream?'
What Graham Rolley-
The young man who took his life-
saw in Vietnam to change his life was military warfare on a huge scale while people in other parts of the world were starving, blood trails where the shells he had fired during the night had landed.
They were the things he told his father about, and how they worried him.
As the years rolled on, Graham, now 36, became familiar with the wards and psychiatrists of Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital.
And now he is dead.
'It was Vietnam that caused it all,' his sister, Mrs Susan Bennett, said:
'He was obsessed by it. He was always talking about it, and going to see films like Apocalypse Now and the Deerhunter over and over again.
''He would say it never solved anything, that it was just a waste of human life .
But he never said he shouldn't have gone. That's the way he was-if there was a job to be done, he just did it.'
Graham was to have appeared in court again yesterday for sentence.
Instead his barrister, Mr Des Draydon, told Judge Gibney:
'Perhaps now something can be done to destroy the public belief that Vietnam returned servicemen are whingers who are trying to make a quick buck out of pensions.'

I realise that this matter sounds sensational. It is all the more sensational to me because it is a reality to which many people want to be kept blinded. On an AM program the same day Mr Des Draydon, who was representing this young man, was questioned by John Austin, who asked:
How can you be so sure that the emotional disturbance that was the experience of Graham Rolley is really typical of Vietnam veterans?
Des said:

Not all veterans do. Many go through it initially. Some are going through it years later. I can only rely on the scientific evidence available. that evidence is mounting. Don't just ascribe it to general madness. This isn't madness. These are people reliving the horrors of a war.
John Austin asked, in effect, whether it would not be better just to forget about the Vietnam war; it is all over now.
Draydon said:

One can't forget about it. One can't say, 'Let's just forget about it, it never happened', and hide one's head in the sand. What society, who sent them there- society sent them there, society has to say, 'Boys, although we may say now we should never have been there, you fellows did the right thing. We sent you there and we welcome you as people who did the right thing'.

Draydon called for more public awareness of the problem and for more sympathy for it. The Courier-Mail took up the tragic record a number of days later on 16 September when Bob Hannah, the Queensland welfare officer for the Vietnam Veterans Association, was reported as beginning a register of dead Vietnam veterans, marking the reasons for death. Suicide and murder were among the violent deaths. The article states:
On almost every page, among the conventional blue ink entries of cancer, leukaemia and heart attacks, there is at least one in red. Sometimes there are two or three, on one page there are four.

Already it suggests that more veterans have died since the Vietnam conflict ended than the 473 killed there but as yet no one knows just how many. Welfare organisations have not bothered to compile follow-up statistics.
Bob and other association workers have had to go to cemetries and find the names and serial numbers of dead veterans and then carry out their own investigations to find what happened to them.
'No one else wants to know,' he said. 'The Government, the RSL, medical people, welfare workers, no-one is interested.'
Nearly all the ex-Diggers were in their late 20s or early 30s when they died and as Bob pointed out, they were the fittest men physically and psychologically Australia ever sent to war.
'Something happened to them there and it's time the Federal Government made some serious attempt to find out . . .'
That is Bob Hannah, the welfare officer for the Vietnam Veterans Association, who was being reported. On 17 September the Vietnam Veterans Association stated:

The reasons for demanding a Royal Commission were strong and clear in 1980. They are stronger and clearer now. Veterans must learn, from a non-political and impeccable source, whether or not those toxic chemicals have adversely affected them.

The Association pointed out that it and 39 other national ex-service organisations are calling for the royal commission that we are now calling for. The following day, in a letter to the editor of the Courier-Mail, the Minister for Veterans Affairs (Senator Messner) defended the Government's lack of action. In doing so he brought up the second aspect which we are fighting for in our amendment. The first one is an immediate, independent judicial inquiry into the effect on Vietnam veterans of their exposure to herbicides and pesticides. The information I put forward, I think, is a strong basis upon which to call for this judicial inquiry, particularly in view of the fact that 39 associations, including the Vietnam Veterans Association, are calling for that inquiry 14 years after the veterans were seduced into giving themselves, at the peak of their physical fitness, for this country. What is so different about this matter is that they are cast aside when other people are feted on Anzac Day and on other occasions when we get together to revere what Australians have done in war . The second aspect of the amendment seeks to increase benefits for the wives of totally and permanently incapacitated veterans. In a letter, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) wrote:
The government has acted to make available free medical treatment in urgent cases for Vietnam veterans and their wives, even if they have no repatriation entitlement.

But there is a problem there. There is a loophole. The treatment is just for urgent cases and most of these people are chronically ill. The illnesses of veterans are going on and on and they are reflecting on their wives so that they are in fear of having a family and in fear of how their children will be affected. They are not being properly compensated. In the Courier Mail of 16 September an article by Ken Blanch stated:

A Veterans Affairs Department officer who addressed a meeting of Vietnam veterans a couple of weeks ago put their problems down to post-service stress and said it was no different from that suffered by participants in Australia's other wars.
He angered the listeners by telling them: 'Sometimes puppy dogs feel sick, too. They go off by themselves and have a sleep and then they feel better'.

I make it clear, as I did in March of this year, to honourable members on the other side of the House what sorts of problems veterans who were exposed to agent orange have been suffering from. We are not talking of trifling medical disorders. The conditions include carcinomas of several kinds, nausea, diarrhoea , weight loss, lethargy, depression, anxiety, fits of rage, insomnia, headaches and skin rashes. The cumulative effect is a high incidence of suicide. Their families also are really suffering. They do not receive compensation. It is now well known that their children may have a number of physical deformities. When we add to this already extensive list of physical problems the emotional pressures placed on a family trying to decide whether to keep having children after one or more miscarriages or the birth of a deformed child we are getting to the root of why families break up or why people commit suicide or turn to crime.

This Government has paid lip service to Vietnam veterans but its expressed concern about the weak, the young and the infirm has not been evident from its treatment of Vietnam veterans and, I emphasise, their spouses and families. Those women are bearing the brunt of the exposure of their husbands to herbicides and defoliants. Despite extensive evidence which has been available for some years about the very real human problem of these veterans and their families, it took until about four months ago for the Minister for Veterans Affairs to announce that there would be free emergency treatment for wives and children at repatriation hospitals. The problem is that the facilities are earmarked for emergency treatment only. I am concerned about the number of veterans and families who are chronically affected by different diseases and do not have access to these facilities.

If this House can hold judicial inquiries into meat scandals or any number of issues which have come before the chamber month after month, why can it not hold a judicial inquiry into what is wrong with Vietnam veterans and the rotten deal they are getting in Australia? If honourable memers are so proud of Australia- they have been saying that during the last week when the Commonwealth Games were being held-and if they are so concerned when they line up with their medals, march and hold their heads up high on Anzac Day, why are they not calling out aloud and why is not someone in this House, which is rapidly becoming deficient and defunct, doing something about this very real problem? Vietnam veterans and their families should be compensated. Something should have been done. If this House rejects the Opposition's amendment and continues to reject the pleas of the returned soldiers it is a sick institution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be extremely brief on this matter; I will speak for less than three minutes. Recently I was approached by a constituent who is 74 years old and who is trying to survive on a pension. Her pension is being eroded because she is looking after her son who volunteered for the armed forces and served in the front line in Vietnam. That son-I promised I would not use names-has found that what happened to him in Vietnam has left him in the situation where he has had to go for mental attention. I think this point should be made and hammered home to this Government: If we have compassion for the people of Australia whom we put into uniforms of various colours we also have responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case I put on the record my concern for a serious situation which has arisen for one constituent. The information I have leads me to believe that in a few months the person concerned will become one more of the statistics that have been revealed by other honourable members speaking on this question. I just put the matter on the record and thank the Government for the opportunity to do so. I ask the Government to have the compassion to look after the veterans that it sent to Vietnam, a decision that I, as a citizen, opposed. Nevertheless, I want to see those Vietnam veterans treated with all the dignity, respect and compassion that they deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) will provide to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) the details of the case he just mentioned.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I am sorry but I did say that I promised not to disclose the names.
—There is no point of order but the honourable member has made his point.

—I can understand the honourable member for Hindmarsh not wanting to announce the names publicly. Perhaps he could raise the matter privately with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. This debate started to be a debate on the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill which is before the House. The honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) in fact gave what could be called a paean of praise to the Bill. He approved of it, and it has been approved of by very many announcements of veterans' organisations. I have some Press releases in front of me. 'Veterans score well in Budget' says Sir William Keys. 'Best Budget ever for ex-servicemen and women' is the comment from an old comrade of mine, Bruce Ruxton of the Victorian Returned Services League. Many years ago Mr Ruxton served under my command, so I know him very well.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a good Bill. It does a great deal for veterans. It picks up a great many things that have been of concern to many members of the Government. There is always a constraint on financial availability, but this Bill picks up some very important factors. It has been hailed by veterans organisations. I received a letter from my own branch of the RSL only this week praising the Bill and all it has done. There is no doubt that it has done a great deal to meet many of the problems put forward to the Government by the RSL and other Service organisations. It is a very good Bill. A great deal has been said about the problems of Vietnam veterans. I am certainly personally aware of them. I have served in a number of wars from 1942 to the end of 1972. There are problems for all ex-servicemen. Vietnam veterans have been treated more generously than the veterans of any other war of which I have personally had experience. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) made a similar point. There is no doubt that the Government has done a great deal. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), who is in the chamber, has done a great deal. Of course there will be problems. There are problems after every war. Old soldiers all round the place realise that. I really do take objection to one statement made by the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling). She said that Vietnam veterans were cast aside on Anzac Day. Nothing could be further from the truth. My personal experience is that that is quite the opposite of the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do. I did not say that. I would not like the Minister to think that I said that.
—If that be the case, the honourable member will have an opportunity. The honourable member may seek the call from the Chair at a later juncture.

—I wrote the honourable member's words down at the time. I may have misheard them but I do not think that I did. 'Cast aside on Anzac Day' were the words I heard. I immediately thought that every Anzac Day I am entitled to march with veterans of a number of wars but I always choose to march with those of Vietnam though, of course, most are a good deal younger than I am.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak now very briefly on the amendment. Any government is always constrained by finance. It is true in respect of the first part of the amendment concerning increased benefits for the wives of totally and permanently incapacitated veterans that the dependants pension for such wives has not been increased for a number of years. Successive governments have taken the view that available funds should be used in ensuring that incapacitated veterans and war widows are adequately compensated in terms of pension and have the best possible medical treatment facilities available to them. As an indication of this policy, I point out that a TPI veteran, in receipt of a service pension, and his wife will receive $22.92 a week increase on 11 November this year as a result of this Bill . Indexation of the pension will bring the total family income to $280.85 a week for a man and his wife. In addition, the veteran is eligible for free medical treatment and the wife is eligible for pensioner health benefits.

The second issue in the amendment relates to a judicial inquiry. The Government 's attitude is that a judicial inquiry would not provide a scientifically valid answer whether the problems that some veterans and their families are experiencing could be related to possible exposure to herbicides or any aspect of service in Vietnam. I said that from my personal experience these sorts of things happen to veterans of all wars. I understand that the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment inquiry on the use of pesticides, which I understand will be completed by the end of November, is capable of covering these relevant matters. The Committee has similar powers to those of a judicial inquiry including the right to summon witnesses and documents. In some respects it may have wider powers than a judicial inquiry. It is for these reasons that the Government rejects the amendments put forward by the Opposition.

One point was made by the honourable member for McPherson. I say the gallant and honourable member for McPherson because he merits that title through the decoration which he achieved in Vietnam. I am glad that the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) had the grace to apologise for the comment he made by way of interjection.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not apologise. That was the last thing I did. I said that he misunderstood what I said.

—I did not misunderstand what the honourable member said for a moment . The Minister for Veterans' Affairs recently announced at the national conference of the Returned Services League that a review of legislation would be undertaken as a matter of priority as requested by the honourable member for McPherson. This will mean a simplification and a rationalisation of the very complex provisions contained at present in the Repatriation Act and its associated Acts. I am informed that the Minister has had discussions with Sir William Keys on this matter to ensure that there will be full involvement of veteran organisations in the review. In this Bill, the Government has done a great deal for veterans of all wars. It has corrected many anomalies. It has also provided for Vietnam veterans additional benefits which are not in this Bill but some of which have been referred to by other honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I would like to explain the situation that was just misrepresented by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson). I am sure that he did not do that purposely. I do not think he does that type of thing. Most definitely he did misunderstand because I am quite sure that Vietnam veterans are allowed to march on Anzac Day. It was not marching on Anzac Day that I was thinking of when I made my appeal for special consideration . In mentioning Anzac Day, the point I was drawing to attention-even if I did become emotive at that point and perhaps juxtapose some words-was that on Anzac Day when many Government members and other members of our society are marching and feeling very proud of Australia and all they have done for returned soldiers , they should think of the injustice being done to Vietnam veterans. They are different from other returned soldiers as they have been exposed to a new element, herbicides, which all the evidence would suggest have ruined their lives and are causing them cancer. Veterans are dying from cancer and their children may do also. The injustice is that they are calling, in association with 39 other associations, for a judicial inquiry but are suffering in the meanwhile.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
