DEBATE.TITLE: DIESEL FUEL TAXES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Mr Hodgman:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr McVEIGH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering the Diesel Fuel Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill, the Diesel Fuel Tax Amendment Bill (No. 1) and the Diesel Fuel Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2), as they are associated measures. Of course, separate questions will be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these three measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I express the Opposition's disgust with what is happening in this Parliament. Once again we have sat only for a few weeks in the Budget session but everything is now being rushed through. Already we have seen many examples of the Government absolving itself from any form of ministerial responsibility. During the last week when the Parliament sat, we saw the judiciary attacked by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Now the Parliament itself is being treated with contempt. The Parliament is where members represent their people's interests. We have been through a debate where the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) took a very strong interest in the question of Vietnam veterans, where the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) wished to represent the people in her electorate and the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) wished to represent an individual.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important that we use this Parliament as the elected representatives of our people to put the points of view of our electorates, various interests and various individuals. But again the Government is riding rough-shod over it. I am told that this debate is to be for 50 minutes as far as the Opposition is concerned. I suppose that all the back bench members of the Government-not one of them is here-will cop it. They will not say a word about these very important measures. I think this is absolutely disgusting. We were to have 110 minutes. There were to be five speakers from our side. We are now told that we are to have 50 minutes. I will have to cut my speech short or my colleague the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) will not be able to say a thing. I just put on record that we are disgusted at the way in which this Parliament is being run.

The Opposition does not oppose these Bills. Their purpose is to introduce a system of rebates on duty paid on diesel fuel used off-road in agriculture, mining, forestry and fishing. Fuel used in residential premises, hospitals and aged persons homes and nursing homes will also be eligible for the rebate. These Bills replace the automatic exemption which previously applied to all off-road use of distillate. The rationale for exempting off-road use was that excise was essentially a road tax. However, the apparent rationale for removing off-road exemption and then introducing a system of rebates for most off-road users is in fact to apply a similar tax on rail transport to that which currently applies to road transport. The excise is to be applied at the rate of 6.155c per litre, the same as for petrol, because the Budget also raised the excise by one cent.

We do not oppose the Bills because they are Budget Bills, but it is impossible to be other than highly critical of what the Government is doing and how it is doing it. The measure will particularly disadvantage primary industry, the mining industry and the tourist industry. The Bills represent another pathetic example of the confusion, the bumbling and the sheer incompetence of the Fraser Government. This Government has proven itself to be not only a disastrous economic manager but also an inept and inefficient administrator. The Bills are designed to implement a measure which has been poorly thought out. They have been amended; they have been withdrawn. Debate on them was called off in the last session of Parliament and now we are finally debating them nearly two months after the measure was announced on Budget night way back in August. National Country Party members and Ministers and Liberal Party members representing rural seats have been subject to so much embarrassment and confusion that they have not known which scapegoat to blame in their own Government. The honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe) even blamed the Bureau of Customs rather than the Government of which he is a member. Admittedly there has been a lot of work on the back benches of the Government trying to get the administration, the eligibility, of these measures cleared up. But it is absolutely hopeless. The people who hope to get the rebate do not know where they are and the bills are mounting up. I understand that some forms were printed after August, and there was another new form in September. I do not know how the Government can print forms when the measure still has not been debated in the Parliament. Is that again another example of treating the Parliament with absolute contempt?

Large fuel users in primary industry, such as fishermen, have had to extend their overdraft limits. The people I have been talking with over the last few weeks fear that they may be eventually faced with requests for forms of documentation that they cannot provide to gain the rebate. Several fishermen have shown me the most basic of dockets and say that if they are given rebates on the basis of those eventually-I do not know when it will be; it is two or three months since the measure was first announced-as they should be, it is highly likely that abuses and corruption will occur. I think we need to take this very seriously. I was shown dockets which are entirely handwritten. I am sure the fishermen should be eligible for the rebate, but they point out that, if they are to be paid on that basis eventually, we will have a lot of corruption.

The people supposedly eligible have had to expend thousands of dollars due to the incompetence of the Government, which decided to change from a certification system to a rebate system fundamentally to get more revenue, to attack the State railway systems and to disadvantage several industries. I could name the wheat and sugar industries-most of the crop industries-and industries such as mining, forestry and tourism. All this was done on the ostensible rationale that there were abuses in the certification system. There were abuses, but they could have been tidied up by recertification, sounder procedures and higher penalties for corruption. What makes the Government think that there will not be abuses and rorts with the rebate system? The Government simply cannot have it both ways. The Budget estimate was that $176m would be gained on the basis of 5.155c a litre. The figure is now 6.155c a litre. It will produce about $210m in a full year or $192m this year. Surely that is not all due to abuses. So the Government cannot say that it is just tidying up abuses. It is simply a revenue measure. The Government has to make up its mind which it is going to be; and I say that this is simply to get revenue.

The relevant Minister is trying to have it both ways. He put out a release saying that it will be easy to get the rebate-details have to be given only once and from then it will all flow smoothly. It looks to me like a paper shuffler's paradise. How will the army of bureaucrats who will have to be employed discern between the fuel used by a truck off-road and then on-road? I cite the example of a wheat truck in a paddock carting wheat to the silos. Fishermen have been cynically amused by the naive inquiries that they have had from officials asking how much fuel they use. Of course, fishermen are particularly angry because the price of distillate has risen by over 600 per cent since 1964, and this is for an industry which receives nil assistance in terms of the Industries Assistance Commission's measure of effective protection.

On 9 September I put a question on notice to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). He admitted in his answer that the changeover to the rebate system was not properly thought out. He said that any change in rail freight for primary producers will be a matter for State rail authorities. I am not sure where that leaves producers in South Australia where the Commonwealth railways transports the wheat. Are they to be excluded from the freight increases? The Minister says that he does not know what effect increased rail freight will have on road transport and the deplorable state of many country roads through cutbacks in funding. The Minister in his answer said that he did not know how much extra income would be earned from the grain industry through this increased freight charge. I understand that the National Farmers Federation has estimated a 20 per cent increase in rail freights while there are other estimates as high as $20m alone for the wheat industry. There will be an additional cost of at least $30m for primary industry; that is, if all the forms flow and everyone gets the rebate. But a lot is still subject to doubt. What about the cane trains and the sugar trains? Do we know exactly how they go for any exemption?

If the Government is seriously concerned about abuses in the certificate system , why has it not seriously considered the suggestion that fuel be coloured so that on-farm distillate is clearly distinguishable from off-farm distillate. The number of inspectors needed to keep tabs on this would be a useful comparison to make with the extra administrative cost for the rebate system in general. I note that the original Bill contained a minimum claim limit of $100. Many small farmers would have been disadvantaged by that limit. At 6.155c a litre a farmer would have had to buy 1,600 litres of diesel to be eligible to make a claim. The Government has been forced to change the minimum claim limit to 1,000 litres or within three months of a previous claim. But I assure the House that many people in primary industry still do not know where they are with this measure.

Under the system of rebates all purchases of diesel fuel will be made on the duty paid price. To obtain the rebate the user must lodge a claim with the Collector of Customs. Claims for rebates will be limited to a minimum amount and users must keep records of fuel purchases and usage for a period of not less than two years. Just how long users will have to wait before a rebate claim is processed is not made clear. It seems to me that this is a rather complicated way to impose an excise on diesel used by the railways. Is there also the implication of widespread misuse of the off-road exemption by primary producers and others, because I note that the Bill contains investigative powers essential for the effective administration of the new rebate system? If we accept that $ 30m or more will be the additional farm cost, it can be seen that while this is a small addition to the total level of farm costs, it is not an insignificant amount to producers facing the prospect of a 40 per cent decline in farm incomes this year, the combined result of a rapid acceleration of farm costs and the drought. Of course, part of the acceleration in farm costs is due to the Budget. Freight is only one aspect of farm costs affected by the new diesel excise arrangements.

Although rebates are to be paid on diesel used off-road, producers will initially have to meet the 6.155c per litre. As a result, any change in the excise arrangements will have a major direct impact on farm costs through on- farm fuel usage. Rural industries, including fishing, are big fuel users, and the biggest fuel users are diesel users. For example, in the wheat industry fuel equals 13 per cent of total cash costs. In the dairy industry fuel equals 6.5 per cent of total cash costs. In the sugar and tobacco industries fuel equals 10 .5 per cent of total cash costs.

In the fishing industry fuel equals 30 per cent to 40 per cent of total cash costs. The figures I have given are taken from Bureau of Agricultural Economics surveys for the years 1979 and 1980. Tuna boats and prawn boats use about 200 litres of fuel an hour and in the average year they cruise for 3,000 hours, so this is very big money indeed. I just do not know for the life of me, if the idea of this measure is to provide for off-road use, why there cannot be a total exemption for the fishing industry. Surely even this Government can understand that fishing boats do not ride on roads. The fishing industry will be the most severely affected rural industry because of the large component of total cash costs of this industry that fuel represents. As we all know, parts of the fishing industry are already experiencing severe economic difficulties.

I would have liked to go through the mechanism of this legislation but I will leave that to other speakers. I hope that there will be some from the Government side. Let us just take some of the implications for the forestry industry and the mining industry. The legislation contains a very limited definition of forestry, including only those beneficiation operations carried out in the forest or plantation. On this basis forest operations will incur very significant additional costs because the mills are not directly located within the forest or plantation. Wood harvested from the forest is required to be transported some distance to pulp mills where beneficiation of the wood takes place. In the case of the mining industry, the definition of mining includes, firstly, the dressing or beneficiation, at the mining site or elsewhere, of minerals et cetera. This would be analagous to the process of pulp making.

Secondly, the definition includes the transporting of the minerals or ore from the mining site to the place where they are dressed or beneficiated. This would also be analagous to the transportation of wood from the forest to the pulp mill . I do not have time to go into all that. The forestry industry says that it wants to be treated equally with the mining industry. It does not quite know where it stands. It wants clarification.

If we look at the eligibility criteria for the exemptions that have been set out for the mining industry it is very easy to see that these measures will add significantly to rail costs for coal producers in both New South Wales and Queensland. The Australian Mining Industry Council has estimated that overall they will add $50m a year to costs. The mining industry itself is still concerned that the legislation is unclear, particularly with respect to the position regarding iron ore miners who process, or crush, the ore. This is still uncertain. In Western Australia one iron ore producer may be in a different position from another iron ore producer. It depends on whether the producer uses a private railway or its own railway or whether it actually crushes the ore or beneficiates it. I have been unable to find out exactly what the situation will be. Fundamentally we have been faced with the fact that the Government is amending these Bills and that the back bench has been worried about eligibility and administration. I hope that the relevant Minister will clear up some of these things in his contribution tonight.

I will not speak for much longer. I wish simply to say that these are rotten Bills. They are poorly thought through. The Government has put up a straw man to say that there are abuses. The legislation is all about getting more revenue for the Government. It is all about putting additional costs on to the primary industries of this country, whether they be agricultural or mining, and the tourist industry. I hope that the Government can come forward with some explanation. All that it has done in the last two months or so and all that it will do until people get some of the money back through rebates is to place an added cost burden on some of our primary producers and other people in this country who are trying to make a living even under this rotten Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKenzie Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on these three pieces of legislation relating to changed arrangements regarding diesel fuel excise I wish to make some comments about various sectors of industry, those that are directly affected by the rebate and those that are not. However, before proceeding I point out that the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) asked whether this legislation is designed to raise revenue. I would have thought that that was fairly obvious. In fact there has been an estimate of the revenue that will be raised. According to my figures, which may be a little out of date at this time, the benefit to revenue will be $161m this year and $172m in a full year. So of course these Bills relate to revenue. I cannot see why the honourable member is questioning that when he himself admits that since they are Budget Bills, horrific as he said they were, the Opposition will nevertheless not be opposing them.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member made much play of the additional cost burden that would be borne by the mining and fishing industries and other primary industries as a result of these Bills. One of the reasons why they have been delayed is that a number of back benchers have been concerned that the administrative arrangements that were originally proposed should be streamlined and modified. I believe that the situation now is that a significant cost burden will not be placed on those people who will be exempt. Perhaps in the case of the fishing industry some fishing co-operatives, for example, which have to pay for their fuel on a cash on delivery basis will have to carry the interest burden for some weeks, but the very purpose of amending this legislation was to make it easier, more administratively streamlined, and not to impose a cost burden on those exempt categories about which the honourable member for Werriwa was speaking.

The original proposal for the administering of the rebate was that it could be claimed only as it accumulated to the level of $100 in value. There was some suggestion that it may be able to be claimed only at the end of the financial year. The responsible Minister has changed that so that the rebate can be claimed once 1000 litres-in effect, $61.55 worth of rebate-have been purchased or once every three months, whichever is the sooner event. That has made a tremendous difference. I understand also that the rebate will be able to be claimed on the basis of presentation of consignment notes or evidence of delivery of the fuel. Evidence of payment will not be required. So an exempt purchaser will be able to make an immediate claim for the rebate once the fuel has been delivered to him, on presentation of documentary evidence that it has been delivered to him.

I wish to mention some other groups in the community which, because of the change in the rebate from an off-road, on-road basis to a different basis, are naturally fairly unhappy about the additional costs that they will bear. I have before me a note which reminds me that my colleague the honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe) pointed out to me some days ago that the distributor was to carry some burden. Generally he has to pay the oil companies the full price of the fuel within seven days whereas the farmer may pay when he gets the rebate . The other groups that are exempt-the people who are involved in charter shipping, or cruise operators-will now be paying the levy. They may well question why they should have to pay a levy which applies for the Bicentennial Road Development Program, but I point out that those operators will benefit from that program in that the people they take on their boats will in many cases arrive at the port of embarkation by road. Much of the money collected under the Bicentennial Road Development Program will be spent on highways that are very close to and serve those areas of Queensland, such as the Great Barrier Reef, at which so many of these charter boat operators are based.

Public transport will have to pay the additional fuel excise. That means that rail and ferry operators, which were previously exempt, will now have to pay this excise. I cannot see that that will necessarily lead to disastrous consequences. In fact, one group that should be very pleased about that decision is the independent road transport operators, who will now have a much fairer chance to compete with State rail authorities. Some commercial operations which have been using diesel for heating purposes, such as dry cleaners, bakers, brickworks and others, will also be affected. In my electorate, an area which experiences cold winters, quite a number of commercial premises, clubs and such types of organisations use diesel for heating. Indeed liquid fuels should be conserved. I think those sorts of operations should have been looking carefully at using some substitute form of energy rather than scarce liquid fuels.

I believe local government has somewhat of a difficulty. I would like to put its case to the Minister because often local government has to pay substantially more for construction operations. In many cases that applies to small local government authorities which have a small ratepayer base. For example, I can think of a number in my area where the additional bill for diesel will be, say, between $10,000 and $20,000. On a ratepayer basis it becomes quite significant because in many cases the smaller local government areas that have a big involvement in road construction and maintenance have a small ratepayer base.

It may be something like $2 or $3 per ratepayer whereas in larger provincial councils or metropolitan councils that do not have that construction activity the additional excise is barely noticeable. Of course, this measure has also reduced somewhat the benefit that the councils were to get from the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. My colleague the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), who will be making some comments later on, I am sure will mention the situation where people are reliant on diesel for power generation for their business activities. This applies to some motels and other tourist operations in isolated Australia which are not connected to bulk power supplies. They are reliant on diesel. This will affect their operations.

The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) asked why it was necessary to introduce these changes. I refer him to efficiency audit report No. 4 of the Auditor-General which examined the collection of excise duties and deferred Customs duties by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. In that report the Auditor-General pointed out that the opportunities for abuse of the system were widespread, that they occurred at the user, distributer and even the company level. Whilst it was very difficult to estimate the degree of abuse and the loss to revenue from that it was nevertheless felt that a change in the system was essential to try to overcome this abuse. I believe that there will be a significant number of additional public servants engaged to process and administer these applications. A figure of 120 has been used. Of course, the costs of those additional 120 bureaucrats will have to be offset against the abuse. Personally I would be interested to hear some more definitive figures of the costs of administering the scheme and the estimations of the abuse.

I wish to make sure that my colleague has time to speak in this debate. Before closing I would just like to raise one further issue. Perhaps the Minister could refer to this matter in his closing comments. The system of making claims for the rebate involves the applicant first making a claim and then he or she will be asked to provide certain basic pieces of information as to the use of diesel and the like. However, a number of people have asked me whether existing certificate holders will automatically be invited to make a claim; in other words, will the Department write to existing certificate holders outlining the procedure that is necessary for them to make their claims or will they, of their own accord have to write to the Department?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate on one narrow interest- that is, my interest in the tourist industry.
—Self-interest.

—No, it is not self-interest. It is very unusual for me to be narrow. I try to adopt a broad view on all of these matters but because of my specific interest in the tourist industry I felt compelled to enter this debate. I think the decision the Government has made to remove the exemption that applied to some industries in some areas has been disastrous; in particular I apply that to tourism.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess that two factors are involved here. Firstly, this Government, which purports to be a government of private enterprise and a great efficient economic manager of this country, reveals itself as its period of office extends-probably in a limited fashion-as being a government of ad hockery. So many decisions are made that can affect the industries that the Government purports to represent so desperately without reference to those industries that it is no wonder that the Australian Labor Party suddenly finds itself not being cossetted by industry but certainly being on a much more acceptable wave length with industrial leaders around this country. The great hopes that private enterprise had for the Fraser Government are suddenly disappearing. The decision on diesel excise is a fairly good example. I do not think the Government really realises the import of tourism to the Australian economy. It is probably the only chance we have in Australia of a growth industry which employs people and which is so labour intensive. Yet it strikes me as quite odd that this Government that purports to be a government of free enterprise has not yet come to grips with the great impact that the tourist industry has on our economy.

I will just relate a few simple facts to the Government for its own elucidation . The facts are these: The tourist industry provides 2.7 per cent of our gross domestic product; the mining industry provides 2.8 per cent; and the car manufacturing industry provides 2.6 per cent. I am sure that some of the honourable members sitting on the other side of the House do not realise just how important the tourist industry is to our economy in the broader sense. When I saw this move by the Government to introduce a new petrol excise Bill, particularly on diesel fuel which, in terms of the Government announcement, was to extend the amount of money that would be available to improve public roads, I was disappointed if not surprised that while the exemption which has always applied to agriculture and to mining was retained that which traditionally applied to tourism was removed. The tourist industry suddenly found itself with an imposition of a 6.16c per litre increase in the cost of its diesel fuel. I apply my criticism in particular to the islands off the Queensland coast. I am glad that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh), who is seated at the table, is a Queensland representative, albeit from the National Country Party up on the Downs. Surely he must realise that the Great Barrier Reef lies off the coast of Queensland; that it is probably one of the world's greatest, if under-exploited, tourist attractions; and that all those coastal towns such as Mackay, Townsville, Proserpine and Cairns exist almost entirely on the prosperity of the off-shore islands.

TALK.START.PARA: —A gift from Joh Bjelke-Petersen to the world.

—Joh Bjelke-Petersen would not know that they are there. He ignores them as much as this Government. He has exploited them and ignored them. To impose an increase of 6.1c a litre on the cost of diesel fuel to these off- shore islands is tantamount to ringing the death knell for them. I hope that the people in the coastal towns in northern Queensland who are totally represented by the Government understand what the Government is doing to the iron lung which keeps them in business-the off-shore islands.

SPEECH.PARA: The criterion that was applied to remove this excise exemption to increase the amount of money available for public roads has no application whatever to those off-shore islands. Anyone who has been to the Heron, Dunk or Hayman islands would realise that there are no public roads upon them. The life-blood of those islands is diesel fuel. As the honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie) pointed out, with a certain amount of ignorance, of course they are not attached to mainland electricity. They generate their electricity by virtue of diesel fuel. They also run their boats on diesel fuel. They run their tractors on diesel fuel. In fact, they put diesel fuel in their boats to go to the mainland to bring back diesel fuel to sustain their electricity supply. Yet this Government, in its unthinking, uncaring and stupid fashion, under this Bill, is removing the exemption of 5.16c a litre from the tourist resorts and is also increasing the price by 1c a litre; so those resorts are now looking at an increase of 6.1c a litre in the cost of their diesel fuel. As I pointed out before, this will almost sound the death knell for them. It is a pity that the Leader of the House (Sir James Killen)-I cannot think of his portfolio; the Minister for nothing-has left the House because I have in my hand a letter from Mr Jim Kennedy, a great friend of the Minister for nothing, the Deputy Chairman of the Travel and Tourist Association in Queensland. It is a plaintive appeal to the Government to rethink what this piece of legislation will do to the tourism industry off the coast of Queensland.

I am pleased to report that my leader, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) , a couple of weeks ago in my company in Queensland made a statement to the Press that the Australian Labor Party in government would restore the exemption that the tourism industry, particularly off the Queensland coast, had from the imposition of petroleum excise. I must say that all of those resort owners, from Jim Kennedy down, are delighted to think that at least the Labor Party has an understanding of the importance to the Queensland economy and the Australian economy of the tourism industry, particularly on the off-shore islands, and that the Labor Party understands the great opportunities that the tourism industry offers to employ all of the half a million people who find themselves unemployed under the present regime.

Of course, most of those people are unskilled or semi-skilled. The tourism industry provides great opportunities for people with limited skills to find employment. As I said once before, no-one has yet invented a machine that makes a bed. All of those people who are employed on those islands off the Queensland coast are basically semi-skilled or unskilled. Yet the Government is cutting off the opportunities the tourism industry on the islands provides not only to employ the people who are already there but also, through its proliferation, to employ some of the people who are languishing in the coastal towns in Queensland and who cannot find employment.

My task in speaking to this legislation is to implore the Government to look at what this Bill will do to those off-shore resorts. Mr Kennedy, in his letter to me that I mentioned earlier, pointed out exactly what effect the imposition of these provisions will have on some of those islands. I will give the examples he gave of estimates in specific terms of what this extra excise will cost those islands: Dunk Island, $30,000 a year; Happy Bay, $15,000 a year; Lindeman Island , $20,000 a year; Hayman Island, $100,000 a year; Daydream Island, $25,000 a year; South Molle Island, $60,000 a year; Great Keppel Island, $50,000 a year; Heron Island, $75,000 a year; Tangalooma, $50,000 a year; and Brampton Island, $ 50,000 a year.

If honourable members opposite were to look at the profitability of the tourism industry in the presently declining economy under their administration, they would realise what an effect this will have on the viability of those islands, what an effect it will have on the tourism industry in Queensland and what effect it will have on those coastal towns which some honourable members opposite represent. It is high time that the Government looked at the inefficiency of its administration, controlled by the agrarian Bolsheviks of a 14-man Cabinet, eight of them cockies, five of them lawyers and only one who is neither and he is well on the way to becoming a millionaire. I refer to the right honourable member for Flinders, Sir Phillip Lynch, who is working very hard at it. It is time honourable members opposite realised that they are supposed to be representing the business community in this country. All they are representing are the narrow political views that they assume. It is no wonder that the business community is generally disenchanted with the Government and is turning to the Labor Party for succour.

This legislation is a prime example of the Government's lack of understanding of the business community. It makes all these ad hoc decisions without consulting the tourism industry or any other industry. Did anyone from the Government go to the tourism industry and ask it what impact this decision would have upon it? No, of course not; it is too stupid to do that. These people have faithfully supported the Government's political line for many years, but their support has dropped off because they realise they are not getting proper representation from the Government. It is high time that the Government looked at its record of destroying Australian industry. This is one industry that has a chance of growth. Apart from the proliferation of tax evasion, this is probably the only growth industry we will find while honourable members opposite are in government. All they have done is made an effort to destroy industry. My plea is quite simply that the Minister at the table relay to the Minister responsible for the imposition of these provisions the view that consideration should be given to the impact that this legislation will have upon the tourism industry by removing its diesel fuel exemption.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that include a return to a 40-hour week?

—He is pretty thick, the farmer from the Downs. I do not know what he is talking about when he speaks of the 40-hour week. He had better go back to his clydesdales and leave tourism to me, because I understand it. Let me tell the Minister that the tourism operators understand it also. They understand that the Government has let them down badly. The Labor Party has made a definitive announcement that in government-that will not be too far off-we will restore the exemption to the off-shore islands and undertake a review of the whole tourism industry with a view to restoring the exemption that it has always enjoyed but that will now be taken away from it.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I leave it there because time is short. I hope the Government will take note of what I am saying to it: The economy of Queensland to a great extent depends upon the prosperity of the tourism industry. Due to the fact that this Government has destroyed the general economy, the tourism industry is in a state of recession. This is just another nail in the Government 's coffin. Unless it rethinks this proposition and at least restores the exemption to the off-shore islands, it will be in dire straits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) spent a lot of time on tourism. I suppose the tourism industry is a capitalist type industry. I do not know what sort of people go to Hayman Island and other such places.
—He goes.

—Yes, I suppose the capitalists in the Australian Labor Party go, but how do they get there? They get there on a 17.5 per cent loading on their wages and four weeks annual leave fully paid. What about the poor farmers left back in the bush? They have to pay for their own holidays. It is all very well for the tourist operators to whinge and cry about an increase in taxation, but what about the increase in taxes paid by the farmers and the extra money we have to find? We cannot pass on our charges.
—Hear, hear!
—That is right.
—He thinks that tourism is--

—That is right. Tourism is a luxury industry. The farmers have to do their work before they can go for a holiday and they pay for their own holidays. Actually, I have a lot of difficulty in supporting these diesel fuel tax Bills; but, as I am a member of the Government and as this legislation has been brought forward as part of the Budget, of course I have to support it. But I can assure honourable members that this legislation has caused more trouble in the bush than has any other Budget item. Although the farmers are not taxed in this legislation, I can assure honourable members that the boys in the Australian Taxation Office are not quite as dumb as they look. They have exempted farmers, miners and other people from paying this tax but, unfortunately, because this will have a compounding effect, we will find that in the long run we will have to pay the tax. Places such as Quilpie, Windorah, Birdsville and Cunnamulla, that have to generate their own power, will have to pay an increased tax on cartage, on rail freight. They will have to pay an increased tax on diesel to generate their electricity. They also will have to pay an increased tax to their local authorities. Honourable members know who pays the local authorities. It is the farmers and graziers who pay the rates. So in the long run they will pay the tax anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure was brought in because of the tremendous tax cut of $1.8 billion contained in the Budget. Of course, that is of most benefit to the pay-as-you- earn taxpayers, of which no doubt the honourable member for Parramatta as a member of parliament is one, as are public servants et cetera. The farmers have to carry them on their backs. It is not as though we have not been doing that for the last 100 years, but we will have to do it a bit more now. But the Government has brought down a good Budget. We have seen a big decrease in the level of personal taxation. Of course, Budgets are usually balanced one way or another. If we are giving some money with one hand we usually have to pick up a bit with the other. That is really what this is about. As a farmer representing basically farmers, I am very grateful that the Government has seen fit to continue to exempt from this tax people in primary industry, mining, forestry and fishing, hospitals, aged persons homes, et cetera. As has been mentioned by other speakers, everybody pays the tax. One has to apply for a rebate by filling in a form. No doubt the bureaucrats are still thinking up one. The form has to be filled in and sent to the Australian Customs Service in Brisbane in my case. Those eligible will get a rebate. As the honourable member for Calare mentioned, this has come about because the system was being abused. Unfortunately, a few people within society abuse laws. This is just another example of that. Apparently the Department of the Treasury was not collecting about $50m.
Some cases were not mentioned. For instance, bakeries were not mentioned. The bakers in Goondiwindi have to generate their own heat with diesel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Burn out the dry cleaners.

—There are the dry cleaners. I have to get my suit dry cleaned occasionally so that I look a bit respectable as a member of Parliament. The blokes in Tara, Goondiwindi and St George have to generate their own power with diesel, whereas the capitalists who live in Sydney-the honourable member for Parramatta lives in Sydney-and places such as that have natural gas piped from Maranoa, from the Cooper Basin, and they are not paying an extra tax on it. One can see that the imposition of this tax has been selective. Of course, we in the National Country Party have fought very hard for changes. We will continue to fight for more changes because we are not very happy with the way in which this tax is applied and is being collected.

SPEECH.PARA: It concerns me that governments continue to tax fuel. I am one of those who have spoken out very strongly against world parity pricing of fuel. I will give the House just a few figures. The crude oil levy is now 16.045c a litre or 38 per cent of a litre costing 42c. The excise duty is 6.15c or 14.7 per cent. Royalties are 0.7c or 1.7 per cent. The total tax on every litre of fuel one puts in one's petrol tank is 54.6 per cent. But if one fills one's tank in New South Wales one will have to pay another 7.1 per cent. That is the position under the Labor Government there, of course. It is a lot harder to work under a Labor government than it is to work under the National Country Party Government in Queensland. We do not have a special fuel tax, but the Labor Party does in New South Wales. The tax in New South Wales is 7.1 per cent. One has to pay 61.7 per cent in tax for every litre of fuel that one puts in one's tank. That is how much is going to government. I ask the House: How much longer can we continue to tax fuel-an essential commodity-to this extent? I have argued about this for a long while. I do not believe we should be taxing it to this extent. We should be looking at other avenues of taxation. I think it is absurd that we have to continue to increase the tax on this essential commodity. In the last Budget we have seen not only a 6.155c a litre increase in tax for some people but also a 1c a litre surcharge to fund the Bicentennial Road Development Program. It is a very worthy project, but we still have to pay for it. Next year we will see a 2c a litre surcharge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you supporting the Bills or opposing them?

—I am supporting the Bills. The honourable member also supported the Bills; he should not forget that. I put it to the House that the Government should be looking at other avenues of raising taxes than fuel. I believe that fuel has been used enough as a milking cow. I know that for every tank load of fuel that comes onto my farm, as the figures I have pointed out show, I pay 55 per cent in taxation. I am paying more in fuel tax than in personal taxation. Most farmers are paying more in fuel tax than they are in personal taxation.
—They don't pay any personal tax anyhow.
—We do not if we can help it, I can assure the honourable member of that. We cannot afford to do so after we have paid all our indirect taxes, fuel included. We have no money left.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity of talking about the Cooper Basin and the Jackson oil field in the western end of the Maranoa district. We have to look at bringing crude oil from that part of Australia, preferably to Brisbane. Some people want to take it to South Australia but, as a Queenslander, I would like to see it go to Brisbane. CSR Ltd-a Queensland company-has done a great job in the exploration of that part of Australia. I point out that in 1980 it found three fields and in 1981 it found 12 fields. In 1981 it drilled 24 exploration wells. This year it intends to drill 36. In 1981 CSR ran 4,500 kilometres of seismic line. This year it intends to run 9,000 kilometres of seismic line. I must say that this is of tremendous benefit in providing employment opportunities, et cetera to that part of Australia. All up, the group intends to spend $1.1 billion in the next four or five years. I would like to see the oil pipeline from the Jackson field, which is west of Eromanga, coming down to Moonie and connecting with that pipeline to the refinery in Brisbane.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with the diesel fuel excise?

—Without crude oil we would not have any diesel fuel. We have to find the crude oil first. Does the honourable member not know that much? I thought that, being a member of the tourist industry and whatnot, he would be an expert on this and would know that we have to have crude first. Of course, the Government has done a tremendous amount to encourage exploration for crude oil. We are now about 75 per cent self-sufficient in this very precious commodity. Worldwide we are seeing a downturn in the price of crude oil. I believe that will continue. It is unfortunate, I believe, that we have gone on to parity pricing.
—Oh!

—It is. We are sticking to the price of light Arabian crude. This is a questionable practice. But there is still a lot of crude in the world. There is still a lot of crude to be found in Australia. I believe that while this Government gives the encouragement that it gives to the exploration companies we will continue to find more crude. That is all I have to add to the debate on these Bills. I support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I thank my colleague the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) for cutting short his remarks so that I could have some time to speak. I thank also my colleague the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) for doing the same thing. It has been pretty difficult in this House lately to get time to speak on Bills as the Government is trying to rush things through and get the House up as soon as it can. This is the third time that these diesel fuel Bills have been listed for debate in this House. We finally have them before us. I understand that they kept being taken off the Notice Paper because the back bench members on the other side of the House could not make up their minds on what they wanted to do about them. After listening to the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), I am not surprised that they could not make up their minds. I did not know whether the honourable member was supporting or opposing the legislation.
—We are not dictated to like your mob.

—The honourable member does most of the dictating himself. The legislation seeks to introduce new diesel fuel duty payments and administrative arrangements as provided for by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the recent Budget. The old scheme of issuing certificates to purchase diesel fuel for off-road use at duty free prices has been terminated. In its place we now have a complicated system of rebates. The new system will apply to those involved in many industries-agriculture, mining, forestry and fishing. The one I particularly want to speak about is the fishing industry. It applies also to its use in domestic premises, hospitals, aged persons homes and nursing homes. The normal rebate requirement will apply. The diesel must be used for purposes other than propelling a road vehicle on a public road. Of course, boats do not do that.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the House that the provisions of this legislation will disadvantage the fishing industry very greatly. In fact, the industry is amazed at the lack of commercial awareness demonstrated by the Government and by this legislation. Surely the Government could recognise that with today's rates of interest on overdrafts fishermen and others will be bearing an unnecessary operating cost prior to receiving the rebate, which the Government itself admits will be delayed. If one reads the sheet headed 'Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme' one will see that the rebates will be delayed for quite a long time due to the complexity of the scheme. Perhaps the Government is unaware that tuna boats use 200 litres of fuel an hour and run at times for 3,000 hours each session. Consider the number of forms to be submitted to claim the rebate, the waiting, the enormous amount of money outlaid and the wait involved in getting the money back. This industry should be exempt from the payment of the duty in the first place. The reasons are quite clear.

Provisions of the new legislation will now require operators of all fishing vessels to purchase diesel at full price and then claim the rebate for duty so paid. The rebate is to be paid at determined intervals. This is an unnecessary imposition of additional costs at a time when tuna and trawl fisheries are confronted with rising operational costs and stagnant fish prices. The fishing industry is appalled at the legislation. I am well aware that the previous plan was open to abuse and was indeed abused. As the honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie) pointed out, the Auditor-General pointed to this abuse and to the fact that it was widespread and suggested that a change in the system was essential to overcome the abuse. The new scheme will not eliminate the abuse but it will lay the foundation of additional bureaucratic expansion to administer the rebate scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —More jobs.

—Certainly it will produce some jobs. I think many more staff will be needed, but where will be the saving? If the idea is that the Government introduce a new scheme to provide more jobs I would support it 100 per cent. But the Government is supposed to be introducing the scheme to save money and I cannot see where it will save the money. The Department of Industry and Commerce will administer the new system and a very complicated affair this will be with multiple applications, particularly for the fishing industry. The Budget was introduced on 17 August. It is now two months since it was introduced. Presumably it will be another month before this Bill is passed and the Australian Customs Service will be able to produce the claim forms. This is causing massive disruption to industry and to farmers as they extend their overdrafts to meet the new arrangements and wait months for their rebates. Surely things are bad enough in industry and back on the farm without this added burden.

SPEECH.PARA: I have slanted most of my remarks towards the fishing industry but equally I could have cited hospitals, the timber industry, the tourist industry-which has been particularly hard hit, as my colleague, the honourable member for Parramatta pointed out-or primary industry. The honourable member for Paterson ( Mr O'Keefe) drew this subject to the attention of the House on 5 September when he pointed out the extra financial and administrative burden on farmers. I endorse wholeheartedly what he had to say. The only time I parted company from what he said in a very good speech was when he tried to put the blame onto the Customs Service. The Service only advises the Government; it is the Government of which the honourable member for Paterson is a member that has decided to adopt this ill-conceived plan. I know it is popular these days to blame the Public Service for everything that goes wrong in a department but I still hold to the idea that the Minister and the Government are responsible for such decisions and, specifically, they are responsible for this clumsy legislation.

I fail to understand why this Government will never learn from overseas experiences. Britain experienced the problem of abuse of duty-free diesel fuel. It did not set up an expensive inefficient, time wasting bureaucracy to delay payments and add costs to the industries concerned. Britain adopted a sensible and very simple solution; it coloured bright green the diesel fuel that was sold duty free to those who held certificates. It proved to be a very successful deterrent against abuse in that police and Customs had the power to stop and check vehicles and sample the fuel. The penalties imposed against those who transgressed were heavy. I suggest to the Government that it colour the fuel green, cut out the bureaucracy, cut out the abuse and save the industry the interminable forms and heavy interest on extended overdrafts while people await their rebates. The Government should let the fishermen and the farmers get on with their jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments are intended to be brief in accordance with my undertaking given to the Deputy Whip. I would like to observe very quickly that until the very end of the speech of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child), the honourable member had said very little other than that people will be bothered by having to fill out forms and wait for rebates. Contrary to the impression that the honourable member for Henty created, the categories of exclusion include persons who use diesel fuel for off-road purposes in the agricultural, fishing, mining and forestry industries. Most of her speech was taken up with reference to the fishing industry. I cannot help making reference to the fact that in my electorate-I am following a little the remarks of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron)-I also have a baker who has to use diesel fuel to bake the bread in the town of Boonah. I do not believe that the Government has intended an extra tax to apply to food, but in small country town bakeries that is one side-effect. I hope that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson), who is sitting at the table and who I know is a responsive Minister-
—A reasonable Minister.

—And a reasonable Minister, will take on board the fact that this is one of the side-effects of the legislation that may not have been contemplated by those in the office buildings in Canberra who suggested this type of legislation as a suitable revenue gatherer. I take the points made by the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) in his capacity as the Opposition spokesman on tourist matters. The views expressed by him are not without some sympathy on this side of the House. Undoubtedly the measure will be an added imposition on the tourist industry. But what the honourable member for Parramatta did not say was that in recent years this Government has introduced several measures which have greatly assisted the tourist industry. The Australian Labor Party in years gone by-federally and in the States-has never even recognised the tourist industry for what it is worth. Any assistance or encouragement has always come from this side of politics. It may well be that the honourable member made speeches so that he could send them out to the owners of all those islands he recited this evening. But let him attach this speech also which reminds him that it is a government of our persuasion, more than previous governments of his persuasion, that has had the ability to recognise the import of tourism, which is truly a free enterprise creation.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I refer to the small farmer who may not utilise as much fuel as is required to qualify for a rebate. There are dairy farmers in my electorate and undoubtedly in other electorates who have only a small usage. This measure will have an effect on them. I grant that it would be a reduction in terms of income for taxation purposes but for some this is an imposition which, I am sure, as I said at the beginning of my speech, those who conceived this idea never really considered. That goes to show that many of the people in Canberra should perhaps spend a little more time in the electorate of Maranoa and the electorate of Fadden to see what life is really about before they put forward propositions such as this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wallis Mr L.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In taking part in this debate on these diesel Bills I would like to endorse the concern expressed by the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), in what he had to say about the fishing industry. Unfortunately I have been told that I may speak only for five minutes, otherwise I would have had something to say on that matter. Perhaps something can be said on it at a later date. My main reason for speaking tonight is to discuss the effects on councils. My electorate is a large country electorate similar to that of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) . I have 24 councils in my electorate. Four of those councils are large country- city councils or corporations. There are other smaller corporations and, of course, the district councils which service the areas further out. All told there are 24 local government bodies in the electorate. Those councils will be affected by this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of councils have written to me expressing concern about this. It is quite obvious that the Government has not thought out this matter very well because, unfortunately, it appears that on one hand the Government is giving the councils something and, on the other hand, it is taking it away. Because this matter is tied up with the bicentenary I feel there has been a con job. It is like giving a birthday present to someone as long as he pays for it himself. This has been the case in this area. As I said, concern has been expressed by a number of councils to which I shall refer. A letter was written to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) by the District Council of Elliston, the third largest council in South Australia, which is situated on the shores of the Great Australian Bight. It stated:

As you would probably realise, this Council's earthmoving plant is almost wholly involved in the construction and maintenance of roads throughout this District. The District happens to be the third largest Council area of the State and has some 1,000 kilometres of unsealed roads under its control.

Whilst your Government has indicated that additional funds will become available to Local Authorities under the new arrangements, it does seem ludicrous to simultaneously increase plant operating costs. It appears that there is no guarantee that this Council will be advantaged under the revised arrangements and it is possible that the ultimate result of your policies will be a reduction in real terms in the funds available for roadworks.

Council also mentions that whilst your policy attempts to direct more funds towards roadworks, it does not take into allowance the time spent by machinery on other works. For example, machinery time is spent on the construction of fire access tracks in remote areas and on-site works for civil construction jobs. It is not ethical to charge a duty on diesel used by machinery involved in the latter mentioned works as these types of works have absolutely no relationship to the road system. It is commonly conceived that the actual users of the facility are the appropriate parties which pay the cost. Your Government-
That is, this Government-
has recognised this concept in continuing to grant exemptions to agricultural, mining and other industries which activities do not directly involve the use of the road system.

That is the opinion of the District Council of Elliston on the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia, and I think it is symptomatic of the general view. In a similar letter the District Council of Murat Bay, the most westerly council in the State , had this to say:

With the expenditure by local government on roadworks rising in a totally disproportionate manner to the roadworks expenditure of the State and Federal Governments, the current situation is obviously totally inequitable to local government.
Road construction costs, particularly in rural areas are rising at a far more rapid rate than inflation, the imposition of this additional burden--
That is this additional tax-

will ensure that Commonwealth Grants Commission funding paid to local government through the State Governments will not be an 'untied grant' in the same manner as previously. Perhaps local government's fears that the 'untied' nature of these grants will soon become a thing of the past, are already being realised.

As I said, that was the opinion of the District Council of Murat Bay, the most westerly council and one of the largest in the State. The general view of councils was expressed by the Local Government Association of South Australia in a letter which it wrote to me about this matter. I do not want to delay the House much longer on these issues. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard this letter from the Local Government Association of South Australia.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Local Government Association of South Australia
2 Hutt Street, Adelaide, S.A. 5000
1st September, 1982
Mr L. G. Wallis, M.P.,
99 Commercial Road,
Port Augusta, S.A. 5700
Dear Mr Wallis,

You will be aware that the recent Federal Budget contained provision for a new levy to be applied to all fuel, the specific intent of which is to channel more funds directly into road construction. It has been the contention of this Association for some considerable time that the nation's road system requires urgent attention and, as such, we were supportive of this move and acknowledged it as a fitting bi-centenary project.

Our enthusiasm is significantly diminished, however, by the statement by the Treasurer that as from the evening of the Budget, all diesel fuel would bear the full rate of excise duty irrespective of its end use. Local Government until then received an exemption of 5.155 cents per litre for diesel used by 'off-road ' vehicles. Councils will not receive an exemption from now on. The extra cent per litre applied this year and the further cent to be applied next year, will accentuate our problem.

The exemption previously granted was of direct assistance to Council road construction and maintenance activities. Withdrawal of the exemption cannot be seen as anything but a clear reduction in the Commonwealth's commitment to the road system and consequently, significantly undermines the value of road funds derived from the new levy. In South Australia, we hold grave fears that Councils may be no better off in the final analysis than they were before the budget. Accordingly, scepticism over the contribution of the Bi-centenary project to the upgrading of our road system is widespread. From our perspective, this is extremely disappointing.

We are currently attempting to compile figures on the cost of the exemption being taken from Local Government. In small Councils, such as the District Councils of Barossa and Owen, the cost will between $2,500 to $3,000 annually. In larger areas, such as the District Council of Coonalpyn Downs, the cost will be in the order of $7,000 per annum. In the Metropolitan area, the cost varies but will be most significant in the fringe Council areas. It seems reasonable, therefore, to assume that across the 127 Council areas in this State, the loss will be at least in the order of $400,000 to $500,000.

This Association respectfully requests your support in our efforts to return Local Government exemption from diesel fuel tax for off-road vehicles. Such an event would not only ensure that needed resources are channelled into roads, but would help restore trust in the fairness of the Commonwealth Treasury.
Yours sincerely,
J. M. HULLICK,
Secretary-General

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope there will be a rethink of this matter. Councils feel that on the one hand they have been given something and on the other hand it is being taken away. Quite recently the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) sent me a copy of a document listing road grants to all the local government areas in my electorate. As I said earlier, it looks as though the councils, like everybody else in Australia, are to get a birthday present for the bicentenary but will have to pay for it themselves.

The main purpose of the amendments circulated is to amend the Diesel Fuel Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 to simplify the process of claiming rebates of duty paid on diesel fuel and to extend the eligibility for rebate to sawmilling operations carried on outside a forest. In the Diesel Fuel Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill provision is made for a rebate of duty on diesel fuel to be paid to certain categories of persons when they use the fuel for 'off-road' purposes. That Bill forms part of a package of measures designed to terminate the previous diesel fuel certificate system which enabled users of diesel fuel to purchase such fuel for 'off-road' purposes duty free, on presentation of a certificate. Clause 5 of the Diesel Fuel Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill enables certain categories of users to obtain a rebate of the duty paid on diesel fuel used for specific 'off-road' purposes. These categories comprise users in the agricultural, mining, forestry and fishing industries, and in domestic premises, hospitals, nursing institutions and aged persons' homes.

I turn now to the amendments which have been circulated. These amendments will remove the requirement in the present Bill that a person is required to purchase and use the fuel before an application may be lodged, and will place in its stead a provision under which a person may claim a rebate after purchase for the specified uses. It is proposed that payments of the rebate will be made on the basis of the estimated proportion of fuel purchases that will be used for specified purposes. The present Bill provides that domestic users may claim rebates at any time but imposes a minimum limit of $100 per claim on all other users. The amendments change this latter provision to allow other than domestic users to claim after three months of a previous claim or after 1000 litres of fuel have been purchased. One thousand litres is equivalent to a rebate of $62 at the current rate of duty. This change will benefit small users of diesel fuel , particularly those users engaged in primary production.

The amendments also extend the eligibility for rebate to milling operations carried on at a sawmill located outside a forest or plantation, including the transport of timber, other than on a public road, to those sawmills. The present Bill restricts rebate eligibility to forestry milling and to the processing of timber in the forest or plantation. This amendment is proposed so as not to disadvantage mills located outside the forest in comparison with competitive establishments located in the forest. Because of the revised criteria whereby rebates will now be paid on purchases of diesel fuel for use rather than on amounts of fuel used in the defined categories, the amendments include provision for the recovery of rebates paid to a person in circumstances where the person initially purchases the fuel for use in the defined categories but subsequently uses that fuel in some other manner.

Finally, Mr Chairman, the amendments alter the provision in the Bill relating to residential premises to make it clear that diesel fuel used at those premises in providing domestic lighting will be eligible for the rebate. For this purpose the word 'lighting' has been inserted into proposed section 164 (I) (B) (II) of the Customs Act and proposed section 78A (I) (B) (II) of the Excise Act.

I mention that it is proposed to amend the Customs and excise regulations to set out the requirements relating to applications for the rebate and to the procedures for claiming rebates. It is the view of the Government that these changes will lead to a far more simplified claiming process for the rebate and enable more frequent payments of claims than would have been possible under the arrangements originally proposed by the Bill.
