INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) raised as a matter of privilege an article published in the Australian newspaper today. The portion of the article to which the Leader of the Opposition particularly drew my attention read as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: Government sources said the public servant's name had been deleted from a sheaf of documents tabled yesterday in the House of Representatives by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden.

The honourable gentleman drew attention to a number of other matters. However, I have now had an opportunity to examine the matter further. There can be no breach of privilege unless there is obstruction of or impediment to the performance of the duties of the member or a tendency to do so. Nothing said by the Leader of the Opposition would lead me to the conclusion that he has been so obstructed or that the article has a tendency to do so. There may have been a misrepresentation of a degree to be decided on a factual basis but there is no breach of privilege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence I wish to make a few comments. First, I accept completely your ruling. I have enough confidence in and respect for you to do that unreservedly. The second thing I have to say is in the light of the evidence that I produced today, namely, that the explanation to Mr Hill of the Australian made it clear that there could be no justification in fact for any claim of a deletion in the sense that documents, as I outlined, showed beyond any doubt that Mr Moore had ceased to be a director of the relevant companies at 31 May 1977 and that any suggestion to the contrary, explicit for instance in documentation subsequently provided for official purposes, would have been erroneously based. I think that was established beyond any doubt. One can reach only one conclusion, therefore, and that is that Mr Hill, or whoever was responsible for that claim in the newspaper article, proceeded to write it in spite of the clear evidence produced for him. He failed to refer to the clear evidence on this matter that had been referred to him. One is left with the quite justifiable suspicion that there was some politically prejudiced motivation in this matter. Allowing for Mr Hill's previous employment I think that is not an unreasonable conclusion to reach.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that this is not the first time I have had a problem with Mr Hill. On an earlier occasion, in Tasmania, he reported matters quite erroneously and in a way which, if they were intentionally reported erroneously, could have been motivated only by a wish to disadvantage the Labor Party and me in the presentation of a particular issue. I regret that and I trust that the management of the Australian newspaper shares my concern about this matter. I hope that it takes steps to make sure that it does not happen again.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Trade Union Activity in the Philippines-Australian Steel Industry and Trade Unions-Adelaide International Airport-Computerised Legal Information Retrieval System-Discrimination in the Public Service-Tabling of Papers

PROCTEXT.PARA: Trade Union Activity in the Philippines-Australian Steel Industry and Trade Unions-Adelaide International Airport-Computerised Legal Information Retrieval System-Discrimination in the Public Service-Tabling of Papers
Motion (by Mr Fife) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise tonight the crackdown on trade union activity by the Marcos Government in the Philippines. This morning's newspapers tell us that as part of the campaign by the Philippines Government against political opposition its agents had shot and killed one of two Catholic priests upon whom the Government had placed a bounty because of their alleged political activities. Another report said that the Australian priest from Perth, Father Gore, is currently being unjustly harassed as a subversive by the Philippines security forces. On 13 August the Government arrested without trial Felixberto Olalia, a distinguished trade unionist and an official of the KMU-a coalition of progressive unions with an estimated membership of over one million workers. Mr Olalia, 79 years of age, was described by the Far Eastern Economic Review on 27 August as one of the few credible trade unionists in the country. Since his arrest a total of 38 unionists have been arrested, including another KMU leader, Crispin Beltram. At least three union offices have been raided and ransacked.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise the matter of the arrest of Philippine trade unionists not only because it is an important human rights issue but also because Australia is increasingly being implicated in supporting the Marcos regime through the economic ties and through the militarisation of Australia's aid programs to the Philippines. Australian and United States Government support is being used to shore up the Marcos dictatorship. This Australian Government has been a strong advocate of closer military co-operation with the Marcos regime as a way of strengthening the region against the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and its ally, Vietnam .

Increasingly, since the lifting of martial law in January last year, unions in the Philippines have been demanding improvements to the appalling pay and conditions under which Philippine workers have been suffering. Wages range from one-tenth to one-quarter of what workers in Australia receive. Official estimates suggest that an average family of six needs 55 pesos or $A7 to survive . Hundreds of thousands of Philippine workers are receiving equal to or below the daily basic wage presently set at 15 pesos or $A2. These appalling conditions explain the dramatic increase in union activity in the Philippines. There were over 250 strikes in 1981 as many workers strived to regain rights and wages lost since 1972 when martial law was declared. The Government's response has been to strengthen labour laws through measures such as giving business more freedom to fire workers, declaring a list of so-called vital industries in which strikes are outlawed and empowering the President to certify virtually any strike as affecting the national interest. In the past 12 months five workers have been killed and many more injured on picket lines. Union organisers have disappeared and hundreds of workers have been arrested in their attempts to improve their working conditions.

From Australia's point of view we are no longer passive onlookers in South East Asia. It is increasingly clear that Australian business is perceiving the Philippines as an attractive area for investment which is able to reap profits through the exploitation of cheap labour and raw materials in the area. The Philippines is also becoming an important source of trade worth about $300m. We are becoming one of the Philippines, largest suppliers of raw materials and capital equipment. As the Australian Government allows our local manufacturing sector to crumble, Australian companies are closing factories and exporting their industries to Asian countries where political repression of workers keep wages low and profits high.

Australian companies with operations in the Philippines include the Dunlop organisation, Safcol Pty Ltd, Australian Consolidated Industries Ltd and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. For example, Dunlop Olympic Ltd now employs some 4,500 people in overseas factories. It has four factories in the Philippines and two in Malaysia. Dunlop's investment strategy undoubtedly seeks to benefit from the anti-union position of the Marcos regime and appalling wages and conditions. This is typified in the export processing zones, such as in Bataan 150 kilometre north-west of Manila. Foreign-owned companies employ some 20,000 workers and two Australian companies, Dunlop and Australia Star Billiards , operate in the zone. The Dunlop workers had a long and tough struggle just to form a union. It is not surprising then that Australia's foreign policy is locked in to buttressing the political oppression of opposition forces and trade union activity in the Philippines. Our aid program, rather than assisting the poor to improve their lives, is providing military logistical support to the Marcos Government. Australia has been expanding its role in developing the counter-insurgency capabilities of the neo-colonial Marcos regime. An increasing number of personnel from the Philippines armed forces have been trained in advanced counter-insurgency warfare in Australian military schools. We have been selling the Philippines planes such as the Nomad aircraft. We have sold it the Dart-the automatic range target system. The military collaboration between Australia and the Philippines Government has been supported by bilateral aid programs, such as the Northern Samar integrated rural development project. A report in March this year by the Catholic Commission of Justice and Peace suggested the aid was useless in terms of improving people's standard of living but assisted the Government's military aims.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to hear the speech of the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe) because no doubt it involves a situation of concern. I wish to talk about some of the effects that the actions of various trade unionists in Australia have on the people of Australia. Some time ago in this House I asked the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) about his meetings with the then Secretary of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia in regard to the future of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. I was aware that the iron workers were seeking help from the Government because they, as workers, are currently considerably concerned about their future and, of course, the future of the steel industry. Of course, the problem with the Australian steel industry is that it is now the most expensive producer of steel, bar one, in all the world. The entire blame for this situation does not lie with the work force. Nevertheless there is some evidence that it has created a problem, as the productivity drop per man hour between 1975 and 1982 has been 6.8 per cent. This has been at a time when productivity per man hour in the steel industry throughout the world has been growing substantially.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem that BHP, as our prime supplier of steel, has represented to other industries was clearly exemplified when the Santos company called a tender for 38 kilometres of steel pipe. The price for Japanese pipe, probably manufactured from Australian iron ore and coal and delivered back to Australia duty paid, was half the price of that of local manufacture. If we extrapolate the sorts of costs throughout the entire energy system that would be applied to the price of gas, we can see that many other workers and many other businesses also would have had increased costs had Australian steel pipe been used. Somebody has to ask themselves who bears the eventual burden. It is interesting to me to note that for the first time a company such as BHP is feeling the brunt of the Government's saying that we will have a halt. I am very pleased to hear that for the sake of all the people down the line who would otherwise have been pressured out of their jobs.

It is interesting in this area of one lot of workers affecting another lot of workers to consider the situation that applied in New South Wales when 400 workers decided that the jobs of millions of New South Welshmen were really not worth worrying about if there was some personal gain for themselves. A similar situation occurred recently in New South Wales in the case of electricity workers. Nobody really cared. One sometimes wonders where the enemy is. In this case I am suggesting the enemy is within. Various unions in Australia have for so long been convinced that the sole enemy was their employer that they have been unable to identify the fact that maybe some of their colleagues, their brothers, are equally the problem. It is this matter which I wish to refer to tonight. There are those workers who get the industrial advantage completely unrelated to their own abilities or productivity. It has been the greed of these sectors of the work force that has substantially reduced the opportunities for others to gain employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about the management?

—I am not saying that that is not a problem. I am pointing out that when one stops and thinks one might wonder, for example, what will happen to many people when the bank workers achieve their aim of a 9-day fortnight. It has been said that the boss can pay. I would like to bet the honourable member that at that time it will be found that the people who will pay will be the customers of the bank; in other words, the brother workers.
—What about the profits?

—I am glad the honourable member referred to profits because I looked at the matter of profits the other day. Profit is not normally consumed in wine, women and song. It is usually reinvested in business. In fact even the shareholder gets little. I will look at one point. The classic example for BHP is the situation enforced by the use of Australian flag coastal shipping. Australian shipping is unique in the benefits that it provides to its work force . consequently the Industries Assistance Commission has declared that this feather-bedded industry imposes a burden on BHP of $25m per annum compared to international shipping costs. Calculated on an income of $20,000 per annum for a steel worker, the burden of this feather-bedding is the loss of 1,250 jobs for members of the Federated Ironworkers Association. It is reason enough in my view for an urgency motion at the Australian Council of Trade Unions. If the ACTU cannot resolve this type of injustice one should question its existence.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfinished work will greet jumbo jet sightseers.

I do this because it was made abundantly clear to this House from this side and from certain quarters on the opposite side that this was a political stunt by the Tonkin Government. The report in the Advertiser goes on to say:

I think it is a 747B--
will be the centre of attraction for an expected 100,000 airport visitors at the weekend.
They-and the Minister for Aviation, Mr Fife-
Who happens to be at the table tonight--
Who will be on the aircraft for its flight from Sydney-will see an unfinished terminal building . . .
The article goes on to refer to the plane as follows:
On Sunday it will make three trial flights of one to 1 1/2 hours, carrying more than 300 guests each time, before returning to Sydney that night.
Regular scheduled services through Adelaide International Airport will start on November 2.
The report goes on to explain that the airport director, Mr W. B. Harris, and the builders stated that the terminal was far from finished. It continued:
Mr Harris said October had been a target date for it to be 'usable' and it had never been envisaged to have it completely finished by now.
Ho, ho! Guess who is having an election in the next few weeks? Tonkin. The article continued:
March or April would be, and had always been, the completion date.

Really that is where one should stop and say, 'Here is the political stunt exposed', as it was exposed by me and by the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) on the evening that we debated the report on the international airport by the Public Works Committee. Anyone who tries to twist my views on the international airport had better have the courage to do it outside this place, because I made it clear on the record that I am not opposed to it. I supported the Committee's recommendation. The Committee was bipartisan. The Chairman was a member of the Liberal Party. The Committee brought down a recommendation. But the Cabinet said: 'No, we are not going to have it. We are going to have it where we said it was going to go'.

On that night, I think I am correct is saying, there were four or five divisions on that question. This side of the House, the Labor Party, sought the suspension of standing orders to allow the Chairman, a Liberal Party member, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Bungey), the right to express his views on that report. He was Chairman of the Public Works Committee. Honourable members opposite refused him the right to speak on that report. If honourable members opposite tell me that the Liberal-Country Party Government was not in collusion with the Tonkin Government to try to pull this political stunt then I will go ' he', as will the people in Adelaide because they are awake to this Government. Not only are we to see this festival of the opening of the international airport ; we will also see the opening of an international hotel which Tonkin, when Leader of the Opposition, is on record as saying he was opposed to. Nevertheless , now he is seeking the opportunity to speak at the opening on 5 November. Guess who is going to have an election in November? It is the Tonkin Liberal Government, which will soon be in Opposition. This facade with respect to the international airport that it has put up, through working with this Government, will be exposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members may recall that I have previously addressed the House concerning a Bill introduced into the Victorian Parliament to amend the Council of Law Reporting in Victoria Act. That Bill has now been passed, having recently been rushed through both Houses on the same evening. This new Act claims to make it unlawful for anybody except the Council of Law Reporting in Victoria, a body which is not elected or responsible to any Minister or to the public, 'to commence the publication or to publish the whole or any part of any reports of judicial decisions of any court in Victoria', unless the reporting is done by or in association with a newspaper, a news magazine or a news broadcast.

SPEECH.PARA: The powers which this new Act purports to give the Council are extraordinarily wide. On the face of it, one now needs permission even to quote from a judgment unless one is a newspaper proprietor. Law students will require permission before they sit for examinations, and lawyers quoting Victorian judgments will need permission before they can send out their advice, create their own private data bases or even write letters on word processors. Further, if the word ' report' is not read to mean a formal case report, then freedom of speech in Victoria is itself being restricted because everyone requires permission to summarise or to discuss in detail a Victorian court decision unless, of course, one happens to own a newspaper. One can only wait with bated breath to see what treasures will be contained in Mr Cain's version of a freedom of information Bill. This legislation does not concern only Victorian courts adjudicating domestic Victorian issues. It purports to cover Federal courts' sittings in Victoria, State courts exercising Federal jurisdiction and State courts considering legislation uniformly enacted by the States and the Commonwealth, such as the new Companies Act. Furthermore, the Council has shown that it will use its powers to restrict publication of judicial decisions and it has restricted the CCH from publishing cases heard in Victorian courts on tax and company law.

This legislation is outrageous and I hope that the Commonwealth Attorney- General (Senator Durack) will move at once to open up access to all laws-cases, statutes and regulations-and to put these laws in the public domain, where they belong. The Acting Attorney-General (Mr N.A. Brown), in answering a question on 23 September this year, said:
We believe there should be the absolute and most extensive freedom in the dissemination of legal matters which are of importance to the profession by way of statutes and law reports.

One could say to the public as well. There need be no delay about deregulating judgments from Federal courts and tribunals and Commonwealth Acts and regulations. What could be easier than to announce that copyright restrictions on these legal materials are lifted for both hard copy and electronic media? Similarly, I hope the Government will announce that it will legislate to open access to the laws in the States and especially in Victoria. That the Commonwealth has constitutional powers to do this is hardly arguable in the light of section 51 of the Constitution and its various subsections, as well as chapter III's powers to make laws with respect to the judicature.

The whole saga of computerised legal information retrieval systems in Australia provides a most salutary lesson. The deliberations of the Attorneys-General and their advisory bodies have not been published and are still secret. There has been little public debate, if any, because there is so little information on Government policies. Victoria, by being, as it were, the first cab off the rank, has been able to steal a march on all the other States and the Commonwealth. By arguing that a government-controlled monopoly is necessary, it was able to give a Victorian monopoly to a joint venture between a Victorian company and a large United States computer company and is able to ensure that the computer company's new $18m computer centre is located in Victoria. By arguing that government- controlled monopolies are necessary and that for convenience there ought to be a single national operator, the Victorian Government is attempting to ensure that such a national monopoly is under its control.

But what is also frightening is the magnitude of the waste caused by the governments. The money spent in establishing government policy, in setting up advisory committees, in paying consultants, in sending politicians, committeemen and their consultants around the world, in drafting invitations for proposals, in the answering of these proposals by companies, and in the evaluation of these proposals and the subsequent negotiations would probably have been enough to establish a computerised legal information retrieval system. If this wasted money were spent on establishing one rather than on working out how the computerised legal information retrieval system is to be controlled, we would probably already have a computerised legal information retrieval system and it would be largely paid for. The shame of it is that it could have been achieved so easily-simply by the deregulation of copyright-at so much less cost to everyone involved and much more quickly.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Public Broadcasting Stations in Sydney Metropolitan Area

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current position relating to the issuing of 'C' category licences for public broadcasting stations in the Sydney metropolitan area.
(2) When is it expected that successful applicants will be able to commence broadcasting operations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 3 September the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal announced the grant of licences for eight of the nine 'C' category licences for public broadcasting stations in the Sydney metropolitan area. The decision on the licence for the ninth station which is intended to serve the Marrickville, Canterbury, Hurstville, Kogarah and Rockdale areas (Region iv) is expected to be announced shortly.
(2) It is a condition of each of the licences granted to date that the stations shall commence operation by 1 September 1983.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Independent Audit: Attorney-General's Department

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice , on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What independent audit is required by the Minister's Department to ensure the proper expenditure of funds granted to non-government organisations by the Minister or the Minister's Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In those instances where grants are made pursuant to legislative provisions, it is required by the legislation that an audited financial statement of receipts and payments of the organisation be provided. Where a grant in excess of $5,000 is made to an organisation in those instances where there is no legislative requirement for an audited financial statement, an independently audited statement is required as a condition of the making of the grant. Where a grant of $5,000 or less is made to an organisation in those instances where there is no legislative requirement for an audited financial statement, a certificate by a responsible officer of the organisation showing that the amount provided was expended in accordance with the terms of the grant is required as a condition of the making of the grant.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Citizenship of Overseas-born Persons

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: How many overseas-born persons in Australia (a) have been residentially qualified to apply for Australian citizenship by virtue of 3 years' residence and (b) have become Australian citizens in each year from 1973.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The figures in column (a) are estimates based on census data and other Departmental information. Estimates before 1979 did not include Commonwealth citizens.
The figures in column (b) include a small number of former Australians granted citizenship.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Port Clinton, Queensland: Feasibility Study for Use as Coal Port

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have Hancock and Wright proposed or prepared feasibility studies of the development of Port Clinton, Queensland, as a coal port based on its excision from the Shoalwater Bay training reserve.

(2) Has the Queensland Government sought entry to the reserve for officials of the State Department of Harbours and Marine; if so, (a) was this arranged through normal channels, (b) were attempts at entry stopped by service personnel and (c) what legal remedies will be sought and who will be charged if such attempts were illegal.
(3) What studies of land use and management in the reserve have been undertaken by Australian authorities.

(4) Was a study made of the potential development of tourist marinas and other facilities in Port Clinton; if so, (a) who made the study and (b) does the study indicate illegal access was gained to the reserve.
(5) Has the Government advised the Queensland Government that Cape Manifold has deeper water more suitable for a coal port than Port Clinton.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not directly aware of any proposals or studies by Messrs Hancock and Wright. Newspaper reports suggest that a feasibility study for the development of Port Clinton has been issued by them.

(2) (a), (b) and (c). Through appropriate channels, the Queensland Government sought entry to the Shoalwater Bay Training Area for a State government technical team to conduct an on-site inspection and feasibility study, to establish the suitability of the area for development of a deep water port. A marine survey of Port Clinton was conducted during August 1982. There have been no known attempts at illegal entry to the Training Area.

(3) The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Land and Water Resources has conducted a wide range of environmental studies of the Training Area for my Department, which are specifically related to land use and management. A number of these studies have wider application than required by the Department of Defence and have been published by the CSIRO. They cover such matters as physical and biological resource inventories, terrain classification and fire dynamics studies. In addition, the CSIRO has prepared, at my Department's request, unpublished studies on matters specifically related to Defence training activities, such as the impact on the Area of those activities and associated works proposals, vehicle trafficability, forest resources, and soil stability.
(4) I am not aware of any such study, or of illegal entry associated with any such study.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Ombudsman: Complaints Received

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) Detailed statistics on complaints received and resolved by the Commonwealth Ombudsman for each year of his operation are contained in his annual reports. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Industry Assistance Measures: Export Promotion

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that, under the industry assistance measures announced by the Prime Minister on 19 July 1982, anybody who travels abroad for purposes of ' export promotion' can receive a cash payment of $50 a day up to a maximum of 10 days.
(2) Is it also a fact that he or she can already get 70 per cent of the fares incurred in overseas travel refunded in cash from the Export Development Grants Board.
(3) Can a travel allowance be paid for up to 3 years without the payee having to export anything.
(4) Was a travel allowance rejected by the Industries Assistance Commission because it found that such a move was likely to increase the scope for deliberate abuse.
(5) Did the Government reject this opinion; if so, for what reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Claimants must first establish with the Export Development Grants Board (EDGB) that they are eligible for a grant; secondly they must satisfy the Board that a visit was undertaken primarily and principally for the development of export markets. A promotional visits allowance of $50 a day up to a maximum of 10 days is then payable as a component of the Export Market Develoment Grant which is subject to taxation.
(2) Subject to satisfying the criteria indicated in (1) above, 70 per cent of overseas airfares may be paid as a component of an Export Market Development Grant.

(3) As the development of export markets is a lengthy procedure requiring persistence over a considerable period of time and often generating low initial returns, new claimants may receive grants for three years regardless of the amount of their export earnings during this time. After receiving grants for three grant years a claimant may only continue to receive grants if his export earnings exceed $25,000 per year for goods and services or $10,000 per year if derived from industrial property rights and know how. Tourist industry claimants are exempt from these provisions but must incur at least $5,000 eligible expenditure (other than fares) before they qualify.
(4) and (5) The Government took into account the IAC's views on the possible abuse of the scheme before deciding to provide these benefits.

The Government believes that the procedures developed to administer the payments will prevent abuse. The allowance has been set at a level consistent with the shared cost principle of the scheme, that is it is not intended that the allowance cover all a claimant's living expenses whilst overseas.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States Military Satellite Supported by Tracking Station at Carnarvon, Western Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Details relating to unclassified US military satellites supported from the NASA tracking station formerly at Carnarvon were provided in the answer to question No. 4235 (Hansard 6 and 7 May 1982, page 2500). Security considerations preclude the provision of details of classified military satellites that were supported by the Carnarvon station.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Strawberries: Disease Risk in Imports from California

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are some Californian strawberries coming into Australia heavily soiled; if so, is the soil checked by quarantine authorities for the possible introduction of animal and plant diseases.
(2) Are many of the strawberries coming into Australia with the calyx attached to the fruit; if so, can the Mediterranean fruit fly be introduced on the calyx of the strawberries.
(3) Is it a fact that strawberries cannot be fumigated or sprayed due to their perishable nature.
(4) Does it take a month of laboratory testing to determine whether strawberries are carrying disease.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Soil is a prohibited import. All goods are inspected on arrival in Australia and if any soil is found as a contaminant it must be removed or the import is rejected. All soil removed from imported goods is dealt with to remove any quarantine risk.

(2) Strawberries are imported with the calyx attached, as it is considered an integral part of the fruit. There is a prohibition of plant debris, which includes foliage, but not the calyx. There is no possibility that the Mediterranean fruit fly would be introduced on the calyx.
(3) The perishable nature of strawberries makes treatment difficult, but not impossible. Treatment will be ordered if insect infestation is found at inspection.

(4) No. Fruit, including strawberries, is not tested for disease on arrival. Permits are not given for the import of fruit which presents a disease risk to Australian industries. Rotten fruit found at inspection would be destroyed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sinai Peacekeeping Force

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether a private company called 'E' Systems from the United States of America, has the contract to supply certain commodities and services to the multinational, peace-keeping force in Sinai.
(2) Who invited tenders for the contract.
(3) Which companies (a) were invited to tender and (b) were among the tenderers .
(4) What were the national origins of (a) those invited to tender, (b) those who responded and (c) what were the quotes given.
(5) Who (a) reviewed the tenders and (b) granted the contract.
(6) Was the Australian Government consulted at any stage.
(7) What reasons were given for awarding 'E' Systems the contract.
(8) What were the terms of the contract.
(9) Was a separate contract for supplying the Australian contingent ever considered; if so (a) why was this alternative rejected and (b) by whom.
(10) What items has the (a) Australian Army and (b) individual troops purchased or hired from the company.
(11) What were the individual prices of the items or services.
(12) What is the total value of purchases or hirings by (a) the Australian Army and (b) Australian troops.
(13) Has the company supplied aviation support for Australian troops; if so (a) what form did this support take, (b) what was the cost and (c) who paid for the support.
(14) Is the Australian Army capable of supplying any of the services or commodities offered for sale or hire.
(15) Did the Australian Army offer any of these same commodities or services for sale or hire and were any of them purchased or hired.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Multinational Force and Observers (MFO), the body responsible to the Governments of Egypt and Israel for supervising the implementation of the terms of the Peace Treaty, has arranged for 'E' Systems to supply certain commodities and services to the peace-keeping force in the Sinai.

(2) to (5) The information required to answer parts two to five of the honourable member's question is not available to the Australian Government. Under the terms of the Australian MFO Agreement governing Australia's participation in the MFO, the MFO is required to provide, at no cost to the Government of Australia, such commodities and services as food, lodging and base support for the Australian Contingent MFO (ACMFO). (10) (a) Neither the Australian Army nor the ACMFO has purchased or hired items from the company. No record of any purchase is available to the Australian Government.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Brucellosis: Cases among Persons Employed in Abattoirs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is brucellosis a notifiable disease.
(2) If so, is he able to say how many cases of brucellosis have occurred among persons employed in abattoirs in Australia in the calendar years 1973 to 1982 inclusive.
(3) Is he able to say how many Federal employees, for example, meat inspectors, have applied for compensation after contracting the disease.
(4) Is he able to say whether the Federal Government pays compensation to its employees when they contract the disease; if so, how many people have received compensation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Department is unable to provide details of the number of cases occurring among all persons employed in abattoirs as requested. There have however been 132 cases involving the Department's meat inspection staff in the calendar years 1973 to 1982 inclusive.
(3) In the calendar years 1973 to 1982 inclusive, 129 meat inspection staff have applied for compensation after contracting the disease. Three persons did not claim compensation.

(4) Where claims are submitted and liability accepted, the Federal Government pays compensation to its employees when they contract the disease. During the period 1973 to 1982 inclusive 128 employees have received compensation. One further claim is presently being considered.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aircraft Passenger Seats: Safety Requirements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he say whether, after investigation into the crash of an Air Florida aircraft in Washington D.C. on 13 January 1982, an official of the United States National Transportation Safety Board expressed concern about the strength of passenger seats on the aircraft.
(2) Has his Department investigated the standard and strength of passenger seats on aircraft using Australian airspace.
(3) Are similar seats and anchorage parts used in Australian aircraft as in the Air Florida aircraft which crashed in Washington.
(4) What are the safety requirements for passenger seats in aircraft.
(5) How often is the strength of passenger seats checked, how are they checked and by whom.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department is aware of reference in a television news program to alleged expressions of concern by the National Transportation Safety Board about the strength of passenger seats in general and in the Air Florida aircraft in particular. Some preliminary information has recently been received from the NTSB and is being studied but the final report and recommendations of the Board is still awaited.

(2) My Department has no jurisdiction on the standards applicable to passenger seats of airline aircraft using Australian airspace, except when such aircraft are on the Australian register. However, since there are few manufacturers of large transport aircraft and all such aircraft are built to the same internationally accepted standards, it is accurate to say that all airline aircraft using Australian airspace are fitted with seats which comply with the United States Federal Aviation Regulation Part 25 standards or equivalent.

(4) Internationally accepted airworthiness requirements for passenger seats in airline aircraft cover the strength of seats, of safety belts, of attachments to the aircraft structure and flammability aspects. Passenger seats are designed to provide their occupants with maximum protection in a survivable accident such as a crash landing not involving deceleration forces greater than 9 times the force of gravity. Detail standards can be found in United States Federal Aviation Regulations FAR 25-785.

(5) The strength of each type of passenger seat and its attachments is checked in structural tests before the seat is allowed to be fitted to aircraft. The condition of the seat, belt, and attachments is checked for damage and insecurity regularly while the aircraft is in airline service. Specific checks are laid down in the aircraft Inspection Schedules which are approved by my Department. They usually take place once every 65 to 100 hours of operations depending on the aircraft type, and are performed by the airlines' maintenance organisation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cancer Patients: Treatment with Use of Laser Technology

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his Department made a grant for research into the use of laser technology in the treatment of cancer at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Adelaide.
(2) When the project becomes marketable, could it be worth millions of dollars to the export market.
(3) Have these grants been at a level of about one third of the expenditure of the research project.
(4) Has one of the grants to a Ph.D. graduate been given only in alternate years; if so, why.
(5) Has the project's progress been impeded by the nature of the on/off grant to that graduate.

(6) When the project is completed (a) will Australian cancer patients have more chance of surviving cancer therapy and (b) will patients benefit from new operating procedures which aid rapid recovery from operations, thus reducing the costs of hospitalisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Health and Medical Research Council (N.H. and M.R.C.) is supporting a project at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital concerning research into the treatment of cancer by phototherapy, in which a laser coupled to an optical fibre is used as one light source. The project is being undertaken by Drs Jacka, Blake and Forbes, with funding of $13,605 in 1982 and a commitment for 1983, and is entitled 'Physical principles of dosimetry for cancer phototherapy with haematoporphyrin derivative (HPD).'

The project forms part of an interdisciplinary team approach to the development of an alternative non-intrusive treatment for malignant tumours. The N.H. and M. R.C. has also supported another aspect of this research, which involves the separation and identification of components of HPD. This work is being undertaken at Adelaide University by Drs Ward and Forbes. Details of funding are :
1980-$19,538 for project entitled 'Chemistry of photoradiation therapy of malignant tumours'
1982-$24,152 for 'Chemistry of cancer phototherapy of HPD'.

(2) The development of phototherapy is at a relatively early stage, and the fundamental mechanism by which it may kill tumour cells is not fully understood and its therapeutic spectrum is unknown. It is therefore premature to estimate the commercial potential of the research.

(3) The grants were provided at the level recommended by the N.H. and M.R.C. after an extensive peer review examination. It is understood, however, that the research is supported by significant additional funds from private sources.

(4) The grant to Drs Ward and Forbes, which sought support for a Ph.D. graduate , was provided in 1980 and 1982 but not suported in 1981. The application as presented to the N.H. and M.R.C. for support in that year did not achieve the level of scientific merit required at the time.

(5) In awarding project grants, the N.H. and M.R.C. specifies a particular term of support. No guarantee is given of further funding of the project beyond that period. Applications for funding in future years are considered as new applications and assessed on the basis of scientific merit in open competition with all other applications. These rules are understood by applicants to the N.H . and M.R.C. However, I understand that notwithstanding the lack of N.H. and M.R .C. funds the project continued in 1981 with support from private sources.

(6) The nature of research is such that it is not possible to guarantee results prior to the completion of the work. The project certainly aims at providing a non-invasive alternative clinical treatment for cancer which, if proven, could provide an alternative to existing treatment procedures and may perhaps reduce hospital costs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Mammary Prosthesis: Benefit Entitlement

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Does Medibank Private refuse to pay benefit entitlements on external mammary prosthesis more than once in a 36 month period; if so, why is a benefit entitlement not payable more often if a medical practitioner certifies an existing prosthesis to be causing ulceration, et cetera, due to a patient's loss of weight.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The approved rules of Medibank Private provide that ancillary benefits are not payable for the replacement of any prosthesis or appliance, including an external mammary prosthesis, if the previous supply for which benefits were paid occurred within the preceding 36 months. Medibank Private has advised that this applies irrespective of the reason for the replacement, except in the case of artificial eyes for children under 17 years of age.

The health insurance legislation is primarily designed to protect persons in the provision of basic medical and hospital benefits. There is no specified provision in the legislation relating to ancillary benefits. Health insurance funds are free to determine for themselves the nature and extent of the services for which ancillary benefits are payable.
Medibank Private has advised that this particular rule, and other limiting rules in the ancillary table, are necessary to ensure the table's viability and competitiveness with other funds' tables.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Citizenship: Adopted Alien Infant

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Must an application be made for Australian citizenship on behalf of an alien infant legally adopted by Australian citizens pursuant to an order of the Supreme Court of a State; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The reason is that the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 makes no provision for the automatic acquisition of Australian citizenship by children on adoption. One of the proposed amendments to the Act, announced in the Parliament on 6 May 1982, provides for the automatic acquisition of Australian citizenship by a child, resident in and adopted in Australian by an Australian citizen, upon granting of an adoption order by a court.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Potato Growers: Effect of New Zealand Imports

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 24 July 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the continuing concern of potato growers in the central highlands region of Victoria that their economic livelihood is threatened by the current proposals for closer economic relations with New Zealand.

(2) Has his attention also been drawn to the fact that the potato industry contrubutes some $16m annually to the economy of the central highlands region and provides direct employment for 1,300 people within that region.
(3) Can he say whether the New Zealand potato industry enjoys certain economic advantages over its Australian counterparts.
(4) Will he give an assurance to the central highland region potato growers that the Australian potato industry will not be disadvantaged as a result of any final trade agreement with New Zealand.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The economics of potato growing in New Zealand, and in Australia, is influenced by many factors. For example, climatic and other resource endowment characteristics, production costs, inflation rates, currency exchange rates, transport and other marketing costs and Government assistance measures such as tariffs, quantitative import restrictions and export subsidies all have a bearing upon the relative competitiveness of the Australian and New Zealand potato industries. On balance it would seem that, in recent years the Australian industry has not been in a position of disadvantage relative to the New Zealand industry since the balance of trade across the Tasman in potato products has been in Australia's favour.

(4) When negotiating the draft CER proposals, which were released early in June as a basis for consultation with industry, considerable emphasis was given to developing procedures which would ensure that undue disruption or hardship for particular industries would be avoided. The interests of the Australian potato industry were kept very much in mind during the negotiations and led to the development of a proposal for the accelerated phasing out of New Zealand's potato export subsidies matched by a phasing out of Australian and New Zealand potato tariffs (over the same period and in the same proportional steps).

In acknowledgement of the concerns expressed by the Australian industry, including Victorian growers, the Bureau of Agricultural Ecomonics (BAE) was asked to undertake a detailed examination of the likely arrangements. The BAE concluded that the relative competitive position of the Australian and New Zealand potato industries will be virtually unaffected by the proposed liberalisation measures.

In addition to the specific arrangements for potatoes other aspects of the draft CER package include the establishment of special liaison arrangements between the Government and the horticultural processing-growing industry to monitor imports and to facilitate prompt action should a legitimate complaint arise under Australia's anti-dumping legislation. More generally, the proposed CER agreement provides special measures to safeguard industries from severe material injury or demonstrable threat thereof during the transition to free trade.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Answering of Questions on Notice: Minister for Trade and Resources

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the Minister's arrangements for the answering of questions on notice, specifying what officers (a) on the Minister's personal staff and (b) within the Minister's Department, are responsible for (i) examining the question asked and (ii) preparing the answers.
(2) How many questions on notice from senators and members has the Minister been asked from 25 November 1980 to date.
(3) What is the average delay incurred between the time of questions being placed on notice and the provision of the answer.
(4) For each question referred to in part (2), how many have taken (a) 1-3 months, (b) 3-6 months, (c) 6-9 months, (d) 9-12 months and (e) over 12 months, to be answered.
(5) How many of these questions are currently still on notice, and what is the reason for delay in the case of each question which has been on the Notice Paper of either House for 12 months or more.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister's staff and the Parliamentary Questions Officer in the Department are responsible for scanning the Notice Papers for questions directed to the Minister.
These questions are then forwarded to the appropriate Divisional Head in the Department for preparation of a draft reply.
The draft reply with the appropriate executive approvals is submitted to the Minister for his approval.

Once approved the reply is returned to the Department's Parliamentary Questions Officer who arranges for the appropriate number of copies to be forwarded to the Table Office via the Minister's Senior Private Secretary.
(2) 169 questions were placed on the Notice Papers from 25 November 1980 to date by senators and members.
(4) (a) 72; (b) 27; (c) 16; (d) nil; (e) nil, 37 questions have taken less than one month to answer.
(5) 17, none of which has been on the Notice Paper for 12 months or more.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Answering of Questions on Notice: Minister for Defence

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the Minister's arrangements for the answering of questions on notice, specifying what officers (a) on the Minister's personal staff and (b) within the Minister's Department, are responsible for (i) examining the question asked and (ii) preparing the answers.
(2) How many questions on notice, from senators and members, has the Minister been asked from 25 November 1980 to date.
(3) What is the average delay incurred between the time of questions being placed on notice and the provision of the answer.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Answering of Questions on Notice: Minister for National Development and Energy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the Minister's arrangements for the answering of questions on notice, specifying what officers (a) on the Minister's personal staff and (b) within the Minister's Department, are responsible for (i) examining the question asked and (ii) preparing the answers.
(2) How many questions on notice, from senators and members, has the Minister been asked from 25 November 1980 to date.
(3) What is the average delay incurred between the time of questions being placed on notice and the provision of the answer.
(4) For each question referred to in part (2), how many have taken (a) 1-3 months, (b) 3-6 months, (c) 6-9 months, (d) 9-12 months and (e) over 12 months, to be answered.
(5) How many of these questions are currently still on notice, and what is the reason for delay in the case of each question which has been on the Notice Paper of either House for 12 months or more.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Ministerial and Policy Co-ordination Section in the Department is responsible for the processing of Parliamentary Questions.

Questions directed to the Minister, or the Minister representing in the other Chamber, are examined by an officer in the Section and if misdirected, arrangements made for transfer to the appropriate Minister.

Questions are forwarded to the responsible Division Head for preparation by his officers of a draft reply. This may involve consultation with other Departments and Authorities, both Commonwealth and State.
The draft reply is cleared by either the Secretary, the Director, National Energy Office, or the Deputy Secretary before forwarded to the Minister for approval.
If approved by the Minister the reply is returned to the Ministerial Section where the necessary arrangements are made for copying and distribution to the relevant Table Office.
(5) As at 25 August 1982 there were 13 questions on notice. All of these questions had been placed on notice during the current Sittings.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Animal Diseases in Middle East Ports

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 15 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was it stated in the report of the Australian Sheep Meat Study Mission to the Middle East, dated May 1982, that the mission was concerned to learn of outbreaks of highly contagious animal diseases in the Middle East region.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to outbreaks of highly contagious animal diseases in some Middle Eastern ports to which Australia ships live sheep.
(3) Is he able to say (a) how many outbreaks of these diseases have occurred and (b) what action is taken by the authorities in the countries concerned to combat these diseases.
(4) What action is being taken to ensure that exotic diseases are not brought into Australia via vessels trading with the Middle East.

(5) Does the Government intend to allow continued trading in livestock with countries in which there are regular outbreaks of highly contagious animal diseases; if so, what are the risks to Australia's livestock industries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Report of the Australian Sheep Meat Study Mission to the Middle East in which the representatives of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees' Union voiced concern has been noted. The problem of exotic disease outbreaks was reported to me late in 1980 in the report of an Australian veterinary officer who visited the Middle East, and on occasions since then when an outbreak of Contagious Bovine Pleuropneumonia was alleged to have occurred in Australian cattle. Disease status in the region is assessed on the basis of the Animal Health Yearbook and the regular reports of the Office International des Epizooties. However critical veterinary reports on specific outbreaks of exotic animal dieases at the livestock collection points at Middle East ports are not available routinely.

(3) (a) Outbreaks of specific diseases are reported by member countries to the Office International des Epizooties. Not all countries are members of the OIE, and the efficiency of reporting varies from country to country. The animal Health Yearbook produced by FAO/WHO/OIE gives an annual summary of the world situation on animal disease; (b) No. There are internationally agreed general principles for action to contain an exotic disease but detailed information on any outbreaks near ports is not available.

(4) Returning vessels are cleansed and then inspected by quarantine personnel before berthing. In some cases the vessels are disinfected. Policies are determined by the Department of Health. My Department has requested that quarantine arrangements for livestock vessels be reviewed at the Chief Quarantine Officers (Animals) Conference, which will be convened by the Department of Health in November 1982. I am concerned that, while quarantine requirements are generally adequate, problems can arise if the vessel is unexpectedly delayed in port while partly or fully loaded.

(5) Yes. Quarantine risks can be eliminated by appropriate, adequate treatment of the vessel before arrival in Australia. My Department is examining ways in which to improve the flow of technical information on animal disease and welfare from regions such as the Middle East.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Government Aircraft Factory, Melbourne: Tender for Supply of Autoclaves

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Support, upon notice, on 21 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the instrument and control equipment offered in the tender for the supply of autoclaves for the Government Aircraft Factories, Melbourne, by Thermal Equipment of Los Angeles different to that offered by other tenderers; if so, how.
(2) Has the tender been accepted.
(3) Was the equipment of the Leeds and Northrop type mentioned in the specifications for the tenders, if not and the tender has been accepted, why.
(4) Was his Department prepared to accept types of equipment other than those specified, if so, were all tenderers made aware of this and were they all made aware at the same time.

(5) Was the price differential between the Australian based tenders and Thermal Equipment's tender the result of different instrument and control requirements being placed on the Australian suppliers to the advantage of the overseas suppliers.
(6) Were the technical requirements for Australian based suppliers higher, and consequently more expensive, than those required of overseas suppliers.
(7) Has any opportunity been afforded the Australian suppliers to tender on the same specifications as that of the overseas suppliers.
(8) Is he able to say what would be the estimated loss of employment in Australia as a result of a Government decision to accept an overseas tender.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The instrument and control equipment required and specified in the tender for autoclaves for the Government Aircraft Factories covered three systems:
A temperature and pressure controller for a manual mode of operation and the required equipment was 'Leeds and Northrop'.
Data Logging equipment for a manual mode of operation and the required equipment was 'Leeds and Northrop'.
Master Central control system equipment for an automatic mode of operation and the tender specified 'Leeds and Northrop' or similar equipment.

Thermal Equipment Corporation of Los Angeles in their tender response offered the same 'Leeds and Northrop' equipment for manual mode of operation controllers and data logging equipment as offered by other tenderers. The company also offered 'Leeds and Northrop' equipment and two other similar equipment options for the automatic mode of operation.

One of the options for the automatic mode of operation was selected as it was less expensive than the 'Leeds and Northrop' equipment and fully met the tender requirement. No other tenderer offered this equipment.
(3) 'Leeds and Northrop' equipment was mentioned in the specification for the tender.

(4) 'Leeds and Northrop' control equipment was specified in the tender as mandatory for the manual mode of operation and my Department was not prepared to accept other equipment. Tenderers were given the option of specifying either a ' Leeds and Northrop' controller or similar equipment for the automatic mode of operation, and all were made aware of this at the same time.
(5) No. Tender requirements for the instrumentation and control elements of the specification were the same for Australian and overseas based suppliers.
(6) No. Technical requirements for the autoclaves were established by the tender specification, and responses from all suppliers, whether of local or overseas origin were treated equally.
(7) Yes. The Australian and overseas suppliers quoted against the same specification of requirements.

(8) While the net effect on employment in Australia as the result of awarding this contract to an overseas supplier as compared with awarding it to an Australian tenderer is not known, it should be noted that Thermal Equipment Corporation have joined with Wessberg Martin Pty Ltd of Sydney to co-produce the equipment, and that the Australian content will be approximately 34 per cent of the total value of the contract.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Taxation Office: Provision of Information to Government Department

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has information from individual taxpayers' returns been supplied by the Taxation Office to the Department of Education for the purpose of checking adjusted family incomes to determine entitlements under the Secondary Allowance Scheme and the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme; if so:
(a) what procedures exist for the receipt and approval of such requests;
(b) when did the Taxation Office begin to supply such information; and
(c) under what circumstances is information on individual taxpayers supplied by the Taxation Office to other Government departments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under section 16 (4) (i) of the Income Tax Assessment Act the Commissioner of Taxation and his officers are authorised to supply information in specified circumstances to the Secretary, Department of Education or the Commonwealth Scholarships Board for the purpose of the administration of any law of the Commonwealth relating to financial assistance to students:

(a) Any information supplied is in response to a specific request made by an authorised officer of the Department of Education to a Deputy Commissioner of Taxation and is confined to specific matters related to data supplied by a person in an application for a secondary allowance or for tertiary education assistance. The Taxation Office ensures that information is only supplied within the terms of the income tax law and that the authorised persons receiving the information are aware of their responsibilities under the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Under no circumstances is any person given access to a taxation return.

(b) The Taxation Office has supplied information to the Department of Education in relation to the Secondary Allowance Scheme and Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme since 1973-74. Before that, however, information relating to certain scholarship holders had been supplied for many years, firstly to the Universities Commission and since 1960 to the Commonwealth Scholarship Board.

(c) In providing for the proper administration of certain Commonwealth funded programs Parliament has thought it appropriate to authorise the Commissioner of Taxation to release certain information relating to a person's financial affairs to a small number of Commonwealth organisations and departments, the authority being contained in sec. 16 (4) of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sales Tax: Commonwealth Games

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Games Flag is a symbol of a group of nations, not just an event, and is therefore similar in type to the United Nations Flag.
(2) Is it also a fact that there is no other flag which symbolises the Commonwealth of Nations.
(3) Given that flags of all nations, states and the United Nations are sales tax exempt, why is the Commonwealth Games not exempt of the 17.5 per cent general sales tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Prior to the 1982-83 Budget the only flags that qualified for exemption from sales tax were those made of cloth, paper or plastic sheeting that were the emblems of nations, states or territories or of the United Nations.

However, the Government has decided to underline its support for the Commonwealth Games by exempting the official flag of the XII Commonwealth Games from sales tax. This is to be achieved by amending the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act to provide for exemption of the flag with effect from 1 January 1982. The Bill was introduced into the House on 17 August 1982.

(2) Does the Government's monetary policy include direction to the trading banks to limit their new lending.
(3) In formulating its monetary policy, does the Government consider the effect of that policy on commercial decisionmakers.

(4) Do controls on trading bank lending limit the extent to which trading banks compete with each other for lending opportunities; if so does this enable trading banks to increase their interest charges on loans and alter direction of their lending towards more profitable sectors.

(5) Does the Government's monetary policy include controlling the money supply which includes liabilities of the trading banks; if so, (a) do controls on trading bank liabilities reduce the amount trading banks can advance to borrowers and (b) does this have a similar effect to direct controls on trading bank lending.
(6) Has the monopoly power of trading banks increased since 1976; if so, is this a result of the Government's monetary policy strengthening the trading bank 'cartel'.
(7) Are the trading banks required to report their profits to the Reserve Bank; if so, are these published.
(8) What is the annual rate of growth in trading bank profits in each year since 1976.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A central tenet of this Government's economic policies has always been the need to reduce inflation and inflationary expectations. A prerequisite to reducing the rate of inflation is to reduce the rate of growth of the money aggregates. In each Budget since 1976-77 the Government has announced a projected range for the money supply (M3) during the financial year.

(2) In the past, the Reserve Bank had on occasion given the major trading banks lending guidelines designed to help restrain the growth in bank lending to a degree consistent with wider monetary policy objectives. The Reserve Bank announced on 29 June that it had withdrawn its earlier request to the trading banks to keep growth in their advances to not more than 12 per cent per annum.

(3) The Government is concerned with the effects of its policies on all groups within the community. Given that the Government's monetary policy is primarily aimed at the reduction of inflation and inflationary expectations the community overall stands to benefit from the Government's monetary policy stance.

(4) One of the undesirable aspects of the lending guidelines mentioned above was that they did, to a certain extent, tend to freeze each individual bank's share of total lending and thereby reduce competition between the banks. This is one of the reasons the Reserve Bank decided not to continue with the lending guidelines in 1982-83.

(5) As mentioned in the answer to part (1) the Government's monetary policy aims at slowing the growth of the monetary aggregates generally. The growth of these aggregates is influenced by, inter alia, the rate of growth of trading bank deposits. The Government does not have any direct controls on trading bank liabilities similar to the lending guidelines.

(6) I am not sure what the honourable member means by the 'monopoly power of the trading banks'. Neither am I sure how the Government's monetary policies, which have if anything borne more heavily on the banks than on other financial institutions, could strengthen the trading banks as a group.

(7) Section 52 of the Banking Act 1959 requires, inter alia, that a trading bank subject to the Act shall prepare and deliver to the Australian Statistician and the Reserve Bank a statement of profit and loss, in accordance with Form B in the Schedule to the Act, in respect of each year ending on a date prescribed in respect of the bank. From this and other information statutorily provided by the trading banks, the Australian Statistician is required under sub-section 58 (1) of the Banking Act to prepare and publish in the Gazette a statement showing , in respect of each trading bank, its liabilities, assets and profit and loss. The last such statement was published in Gazette No. G 31 of 3 August 1982. The banks themselves publish profit statements in accordance with Companies Act and Stock Exchange listing requirements.

(8) Comparative analysis of bank profits is materially affected by the treatment of extraordinary items, intra-group dividends, determination of expenses and provisions, changes in corporate structure and ownership of subsidiaries, changes in accounting standards and other relevant factors.

Within the period covered by the question there have, in particular, been changes in disclosures practices by banks which have had significant effects on stated profits. This development followed my Press statement of 17 September 1978 of the Government's intention to amend the reporting forms prescribed under the Banking Act to bring the basis of reporting by banks closer to that of other companies. In particular, the balances of inner reserves, except for bad and doubtful debts, were in future to form part of shareholders' funds. These changes in disclosure had the effect of raising reported profits. Although these accounting adjustments were introduced at different times by the banks over their 1978 and 1979 reporting years, some impression of their significance can be obtained by comparing the reported profits for 1978 in the banks' 1978 annual reports with the profits reported for that year in the banks' 1979 annual reports.

Against that background it is apparent that a variety of calculations concerning profit growth could be made on the basis of different assumptions. The figures below show major trading bank profits as reported in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. In assessing the figures I refer the honourable member to the respective Gazettes and to the banks' annual reports and accounts and relevant statements therein.
