ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Taxation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Federal Government package of taxes progressive as opposed to the impositions of State and local government income tax.
(2) What evidence can he provide to support his answer to (1).
(3) In assessing the relativities of the 2 systems is it necessary to take into account tax evasion and tax avoidance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) Local governments have never imposed an income tax in Australia and State Governments have not imposed such a tax since the introduction of uniform taxation in 1942. Accordingly, it is not possible to compare Commonwealth taxes with State and local government income tax.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Holsworthy Army Base, New South Wales: Noise Levels of Gunfire

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many complaints have been received in each of the last 5 years regarding the noise level of gunfire at the artillery range at Holsworthy, N.S.W .
(2) How are these complaints treated.
(3) How many claims for compensation in respect of detonations at Holsworthy have been received.
(4) How many have been successful.
(5) What are the criteria used in assessing these claims.

(6) Are detonations occurring at the Holsworthy range capable of causing (a) nuisance distress to people and pets and (b) damage to foundations, cement rendering and bathroom and kitchen tiles of domestic residences.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 220 telephone complaints have been received over the past 5 years and although no firm figures are available, it is estimated that no more than 12 written complaints are received annually.
The following numbers of telephone calls were received:
(2) Complaints are treated in two ways:
(a) Telephone Callers. Details of telephone complaints are recorded by Duty Officers. Callers are informed of the factors which contribute to the intensity of the noise.

(b) Written Complaints. Each is acknowledged. Advice is provided on the necessity for training activities and the actions taken by Army to minimise disturbance to residents consistent with meeting training objectives.
(3) Eight claims for compensation have been received in respect of detonations at Holsworthy.

(5) Each claim for compensation for alleged damages is investigated by an officer who is a Civil Engineer, attached to HQ 2 Military District. Completed investigations are referred to the Deputy Crown Solicitor for determination.

(6) The effects of detonations emanating from the Holsworthy range are, as previously stated, being investigated by the National Acoustics Laboratory. An investigation conducted in 1979 by the Bureau of Mineral Resources suggested that:

'the low readings of ground and air vibrations measured at locations within the nearby civil communities indicated that any annoyance suffered as a result of weapons firing was, essentially, acoustical'.

Also, technical assessments indicate that it is highly improbable that range detonations could cause damage to foundations especially at the distance the civilian dwellings are from impact areas. Damage to cement rendering and bathroom and kitchen tiles of domestic residences are more likely due to the expansion and contraction characteristics of the soil in the area which has a very high clay content.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Holsworthy Army Base, New South Wales: Noise Levels of Gunfire

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the main features of the National Acoustics Laboratory report on the noise levels of firing at Holsworthy Army Base, N.S.W.
(2) What action (a) has been taken and (b) is contemplated following receipt of the report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Acoustics Laboratory report on noise levels of firing at Holsworthy Army Base, N.S.W., has not yet been received.
(2) No action has (a) been taken and (b) is contemplated until the report is received.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Holsworthy Artillery Range, New South Wales: Firing of Explosive Charges

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Are there any restrictions placed on the firing of explosive charges at the Holsworthy Artillery Range, N.S.W.; if so, what restrictions are placed on their (a) frequency and (b) duration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows.

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. Firing of explosive charges at the Holsworthy Range, N.S.W., is restricted to the following periods:
(a) Monday to Saturday, 0700 hours to 2100 hours.
(b) Sundays and Public Holidays, 0900 hours to 1900 hours.
Within these time frames the duration of firing is not restricted.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Holsworthy Artillery Range, New South Wales: Bush Fires

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there any evidence to show that artillery fire at the Holsworthy Artillery Range, NSW, has caused bush fires (a) on the range and (b) in the surrounding countryside.
(2) If so, (a) when did each incident occur and (b) was there any damage to (i) Army or (ii) domestic property.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) There is evidence to indicate that artillery fire at the Holsworthy Artillery Range, NSW, may have caused bush fires on the range, and
(b) There is no evidence to suggest that artillery fire has caused bush fires in the surrounding countryside.
(2) (a) Fires started on the range, not necessarily in the impact area, on the following days when artillery were firing:
1981-11, 20, 24, 27 March; 2 April; 13 May; 13, 25 August; 10, 13, 24 September ; 1, 5 October.

(b) Only one fire has spread off the range. This fire occurred spontaneously and linked with other fires burning in the area. Artillery were not being exercised on this day. There are no reports of damage to army or domestic property.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Independent Audit: Department of Administrative Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What independent audit is required by the Minister's Department to ensure the proper expenditure of funds granted to non-government organisations by the Minister or the Minister's Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A condition of grants to international conferences held in Australia is that a statement of income and expenditure for the conference, audited by a qualified public accountant, should be submitted to the Department of Administrative Services as soon as possible after the conference.
Organisations in receipt of grants-in-aid are required to submit an audited financial statement in respect of the year in which a grant was made to the Department of Administrative Services.
